San Francisco Apologizes to Artist Over Maya Angelou Monument
description: The decision to build a monument honoring the poet and civil rights activist Maya Angelou was supposed to jump-start San Franciscos planned diversification of city sculptures; instead, an opaque selection process has opened new wounds between public officials and local artists.

title: Health Experts to F.D.A.: Make Your Vaccine Deliberations Public
description: A coalition of leading public health experts urged the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday night to conduct full safety and efficacy reviews of potential coronavirus vaccines before making the products widely available to the public.

title: C.D.C. Warns Against Drinking Hand Sanitizer
description: Federal health authorities issued a formal warning on Wednesday about the dangers of drinking hand sanitizer and alerted poison control centers across the nation to be on the lookout for cases of methanol toxicity after four people died and nearly a dozen became ill.

title: By Any Other Name
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  One of the best things about solving crossword puzzles, in my opinion, is the opportunity to learn something new. My Crosswords Live co-host, Sam Ezersky, and I talk about this a lot, especially when a viewer asks How am I supposed to know that?

title: Quotation of the Day: Lebanon Knew of Danger for Years. It Didnt Act.
description: This is as bad as Sept. 11. For us, it is like that.

title: Corrections: Aug. 6, 2020
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about plasma infusions as a coronavirus treatment misstated the network that runs Lou Dobbs Tonight. It is Fox Business Network, not Fox News.

title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in August
description: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for August.

title: The Hiroshima Pilot Who Became a Symbol of Antinuclear Protest
description: The latest article from Beyond the World War II We Know, a series from The Times that documents lesser-known stories from the war, looks at Claude Eatherly, an American pilot involved in the atomic bombing of Hiroshima. After years of being arrested for petty crimes, he became a high-profile antinuclear activist.

title: How We Retain the Memory of Japans Atomic Bombings: Books
description: In the latest article from Beyond the World War II We Know, a series by The Times that documents lesser-known stories from the war, we asked Yoko Ogawa, an award-winning Japanese author, to reflect on the literature unleashed by the atomic bombings. This article was translated by Stephen Snyder.

title: After Atomic Bombings, These Photographers Worked Under Mushroom Clouds
description: In August 1945, a Japanese newspaper sent a photographer from Tokyo to two cities that the United States military had just leveled with atomic bombs.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Rescue workers, still struggling to treat thousands of people wounded in the enormous explosion in Beirut, turned their attention to the desperate search for survivors.

title: Police Identify Suspect in Seattle Killing During June Protests
description: The police have identified a suspect and prosecutors decided to charge him with first-degree murder in the fatal shooting of a man in June that took place during protests in Seattle seeking racial justice, the authorities said on Wednesday.

title: LeBron James Says He Doesnt Care if Trump Shuns N.B.A. Over Protests
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.  LeBron James of the Los Angeles Lakers provided a pointed response on Wednesday night to President Trumps criticism of players kneeling during the national anthem: The games will go on without you watching.

title: Whats on TV Thursday: An American Pickle and Shawshank Redemption
description: AN AMERICAN PICKLE (2020) Stream on HBO. In 1919, Herschel Greenbaum (Seth Rogen) and his wife, Sarah (Sarah Snook), emigrated from their fictional Eastern European home country  a place called Schlupsk  to New York City, where they dreamed of building a better life for generations of Greenbaums to come. But one fateful day, Herschel fell into a vat of brine at a pickle factory, where he worked. When Herschel emerged from the pickle vat, perfectly preserved 100 years later, he found there was only one Greenbaum left: his great-grandson, Ben (also Rogen). With Ben, Herschel becomes determined to refine the Greenbaum legacy once more. The films screenplay is written by Simon Rich and is adapted from his 2013 novella, Sell Out.

title: Late Night Says Trump Ran Back to the Comfort of Fox News
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous nights highlights that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Many of us are stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Fair Balls and Foul Language
description: The frustration was understandable. After striking out Yankees first baseman Luke Voit to end a tough inning that included walking two batters, Boston Red Sox pitcher Austin Brice stomped off the mound on Sunday while berating himself.

title: How Harding Park Became the Most Unpretentious Site to Host a Major
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Fewer than three weeks ago, T.P.C. Harding Park, a city-owned golf course, was roamed by duffers of all abilities. Those were just another stretch of crowded days at the local muni.

title: A Nobel Laureates New Play Revives a Tragic, Forgotten Figure
description: SALZBURG, Austria  Theres an unfamiliar name among all the stars on the posters for this summers truncated Salzburg Festival: Zdenek Adamec.

title: Judge John Hodgman on Walking and Talking
description: Doug writes: My girlfriend, Susan, and I enjoy long, brisk walks and quickly fall into great conversations. Oft times, after I share a witty remark, she stops in her tracks to laugh, leaving me walking alone, sometimes for 15 to 20 seconds. Her habit interrupts the flow of our clever banter. She argues she has the right to react as she sees fit.

title: Outdoor Space or an Extra Bedroom? Two Manhattan Renters on a Budget Have to Choose
description: For their first place together, a young couple scanned the Upper West Side in the midst of the pandemic. Which of these homes would you have chosen?

title: You Cant Avoid Death, but You Can Make It Easier
description: LIFE EVENTSBy Karolina Waclawiak

title: In Luster, Young Black Women Feel Uneasy in a White American Home
description: LUSTER By Raven Leilani

title: Is Your Child an Orchid, a Tulip or a Dandelion?
description: The new mother from a rural area near Burlington, Vt., noticed that her toddlers behavior didnt seem to fit the descriptions in the child-rearing books she was reading.

title: Unfortunately, Eddie S. Glaude Jr.s Book Is Well-Timed
description: WRITERS BLOCK Eddie S. Glaude Jr. says he first envisioned Begin Again, now at No. 5 on the hardcover nonfiction list, as an intellectual biography of James Baldwin: But then I ran into this wall. A year went by and I hadnt written a sentence.

title: Trump Supporters Make Their Case for 2020
description: Listen and subscribe to The Argument from your mobile device:

title: Five-Minute Coronavirus Stress Resets
description: In this emotional equivalent to an ultramarathon, its key to have some stress-reducing strategies available that work quickly and efficiently to help you hit the reset button.

title: I Used My Bomb Training to Report on the Beirut Explosions
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: Boxed Into a Corner, Sturgis Braces for Thousands to Attend Motorcycle Rally
description: For most of the year, Sturgis, S.D., is a relatively quiet city of 7,000 residents tucked beside a 1.2 million-acre forest, with a motorcycle museum as its signature attraction. But each summer, Sturgis transforms as bikers descend for a massive motorcycle rally.

title: Poem: i want to speak of unity
description: Each of us carries a cord of hope through all our wandering days. Where it begins, when we found ourselves leaving home  so many homes; or when we arrived, when consciousness widened to possibilities of community  the cord grows stronger or frays. Juan Felipe Herreras magnificent new poems in Every Day We Get More Illegal testify to the deepest parts of the American dream  the streets and parking lots, the stores and restaurants and futures that belong to all  from the times when hope was bright, more like an intimate song than any anthem stirring the blood. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

title: Dont Fall for Trumps Census Bait-and-Switch
description: Last month, President Trump ordered the Commerce Department to do what it legally could to exclude undocumented immigrants from the census count used to redraw congressional districts. Then on Monday, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross announced that the constitutionally mandated 2020 census would end a month early.

title: The Teenage Tinkerer Behind an E-Bike Revolution
description: The residents of Garberville, Calif., didnt know what to make of 15-year-old Mike Radenbaugh and the odd motorized bikes he was concocting in his familys garage.

title: The Real Reason the American Economy Boomed After World War II
description: The United States long reserved its most lucrative occupations for an elite class of white men. Those men held power by selling everyone else a myth: The biggest threat to workers like you are workers who do not look like you. Again and again, they told working-class white men that they were losing out on good jobs to women, nonwhite men and immigrants.

title: Congresss Ideological Divide Has Stymied Aid for Pandemic-Stricken Schools
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans and Democrats in Congress say they agree that a new stimulus package must include billions of dollars to help schools struggling financially and logistically to resume education this month and next.

title: Out Stealing Horses Review: Old Man, Take a Look at Your Life
description: Adapted from the highly acclaimed 2003 novel by Per Petterson, Out Stealing Horses, written and directed by Hans Petter Moland, is an ambitious film that examines memory and consciousness through the perspective of an older man whos determined to escape from memory and to constrict his lived experience.

title: Mike Fiers Is Moving On, Just Like He Always Has
description: It wasnt exactly the 2020 debut Mike Fiers had spent an interrupted spring training and abbreviated summer camp envisioning. When he finally got on the mound for a real game on Major League Baseballs opening weekend, Oaklands right-handed pitcher allowed seven hits and four runs  three of them on a mighty home run by Mike Trout. Despite his ordinary performance, the Athletics still beat the Los Angeles Angels, 6-4.

title: Racism Makes a Liar of God
description: In 1963, when 250,000 demonstrators gathered at the Lincoln Memorial and heard the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.s I have a dream speech, they did so under the prayerful invocation of Archbishop Patrick OBoyle of Washington. He called for the Holy Spirit to open the eyes of Christians to the injustice of racial discrimination, condemned violence and praised the activists who had possessed the courage to go forth, like Moses, in search of a beautiful country.

title: Classical Music Attracts Older Audiences. Good.
description: The coronavirus pandemic poses a grave challenge to all of the performing arts. There are few ways to mitigate the risk from packing performers and audiences tightly together without fundamentally altering the experience of these art forms, which thrive on crowds.

title: Who Was Behind the Largest Mass Arrest in U.S. History?
description: In the spring of 1971, Richard Nixon found himself in a situation not unlike President Trumps. His approval rating was falling  in Mr. Nixons case, to a first-term low  just as an energetic social movement was hitting the streets. Like Mr. Trump, Mr. Nixon was tempted to use military force to counter those dissenters. And like the current president, Mr. Nixon and his aides found a way around the Pentagons resistance.

title: White Customers, Black Fabrics
description: The recent outpouring of support for Black-owned businesses has brought attention to fashion labels that work with African prints. The labels, many of them founded by West African designers living in the United States and Britain, are turning the traditional patterns of West African fabric into contemporary American silhouettes.

title: Its Kitchen Sink Time: Fast, Less-Accurate Coronavirus Tests May Be Good Enough
description: For months, the call for coronavirus testing has been led by one resounding refrain: To keep outbreaks under control, doctors and researchers need to deploy the most accurate tests available  ones reliable enough to root out as many infections as possible, even in the absence of symptoms.

title: A Family Cries Justice for Hannah. Will Its Rural Town Listen?
description: SEDALIA, Mo.  Seven weeks had passed, and still there were no answers. So once again, a small cluster of friends and family gathered in the leafy courthouse square and marched for Hannah Fizer, an unarmed woman shot and killed by a rural Missouri sheriffs deputy during a traffic stop.

title: Self-Publishing Is a Gamble. Why Is Donald Trump Jr. Doing It?
description: There is a lot about Donald Trump Jr.s second book that is unusual.

title: Its Time for a Change: Workers Idled by the Virus Try New Careers
description: MANCHESTER, England  As a national lockdown was imposed in March, a food deliverer, Hanna Scaife, watched her weekly hours plummet from 30, to five, then to zero as restaurants across Teesside, in northeast England, shut their doors.

title: Witnessing Nuclear Carnage, Then Devoting Her Life to Peace
description: On the morning of Aug. 6, 1945, Setsuko Thurlow, then just 13, reported for her first full day of duty in Japans increasingly desperate war effort. Together with 30 other girls, she had been recruited to assist with code breaking at a military office in Hiroshima.

title: Motorcycle of Tomorrow Is Heavy on Flair and Light on the Environment
description: Metal. Rubber. Leather. When it comes to motorcycles, the materials used to make them are as elemental as the experience of riding them.

title: Anatomy of a Public Pool in a Pandemic
description: The timeless soundtrack of a public pool in summer is largely silent this summer. No shrieking children, no splashy entrances or periodic whistle blasts and curt admonitions from lifeguards (Walk! Dont run!), little of the buzzy hum of happy people chatting in and around the water.

title: The Unique U.S. Failure to Control the Virus
description: Nearly every country has struggled to contain the coronavirus and made mistakes along the way.

title: Water, Sand and Plenty of Elbow Room on 8 Wild, Protected Coastlines
description: The grandmother of American conservation, Mardy Murie, once called the national parks our best idea. And this year, with foreign travel all but canceled, some of these celebrated domestic destinations have reached new heights of jam-packed popularity  and that, of course, presents challenges during a pandemic.

title: New Yorks Sidewalk Prophets Are Heirs of the Artisans of Frances Lascaux Caves
description: About 17,000 years ago, in the caves of Lascaux, France, ancestors drew on grotto walls, depicting equines, stags, bison, aurochs and felines. They wanted to convey to other humans a political reality crucial to their survival: They shared their environment with other beings that looked and behaved differently from them.

title: Luster, by Raven Leilani: An Excerpt
description: The first time we have sex, we are both fully clothed, at our desks during working hours, bathed in blue computer light. He is uptown processing a new bundle of microfiche and I am downtown handling corrections for a new Labrador detective manuscript. He tells me what he ate for lunch and asks if I can manage to take off my underwear in my cubicle without anyone noticing. His messages come with impeccable punctuation. He is fond of words like taste and spread. The empty text field is full of possibilities. Of course I worry about IT remoting into my computer, or my internet history warranting yet another disciplinary meeting with HR. But the risk. The thrill of a third pair of unseen eyes. The idea that someone in the office, with that sweet, post-lunch-break optimism, might come across the thread and see how tenderly Eric and I have built this private world.

title: Real Life Horror Stories From the World of Pandemic Motherhood
description: Employers are using the pandemic to get rid of mothers, and our attempts to protect them are failing.

title: Hours of Talks on U.S. Coronavirus Relief End With No Deal
description: This briefing has ended. Read live coronavirus updates here.

title: After Isaias, When Will Power Be Back?
description: [Want to get New York Today by email? Heres the sign-up.]

title: Idled by the pandemic, workers in Britain try new careers.
description: The economic collapse caused by the coronavirus has put millions of economic futures in doubt. More than nine million people have been furloughed in Britain, or 29 percent of the countrys work force, and 2.8 million have filed unemployment claims.

title: A majority of travelers are not willing to get on planes, a new survey shows.
description: More than half of Americans who flew in the past year are not ready to do so again, according to a new survey, underscoring the difficulty airlines face in convincing people it is safe for them to get back on planes.

title: Chinas Offer to Help With Virus Testing Spooks Hong Kong
description: The offer was presented as a favor to Hong Kong, a city struggling with a surge in coronavirus infections: a team of 60 medical officials from mainland China who would help expand testing across the city.

title: Britains economy wont fully recover till end of 2021, its central bankers said.
description: The Bank of England presented both a better and worse outlook for the British economy on Thursday. As the central bank left its monetary policy stance unchanged, policymakers said that they expected the British economy to contract by 9.5 percent this year, a less severe downturn than they indicated a few months ago, and the unemployment rate would peak at 7.5 percent at the end of the year.

title: America Stands Alone
description: Nearly every country has struggled to contain the coronavirus. But only one affluent nation has suffered a severe, sustained outbreak for more than four months: the United States.

title: Episode Three: This Is Our School, How Dare You?
description: Chana Joffe-Walt explores how white parents can shape a school  even when they arent there.

title: The Day That Shook Beirut
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

title: Restricting Beach Access to Residents Only
description: Connecticut and New York residents who dont live along the coast are likely feeling the heat more than usual this summer, as one town after another has closed off its beaches to everyone except locals.

title: The Secret Garden Review: Its as Lovely as You Remember
description: In a year defined by surprise, the predictability of The Secret Garden  a new film adaptation of Frances Hodgson Burnetts beloved 1911 novel  proves more charming than tedious.

title: Waiting for the Barbarians Review: An Aestheticized Fable of Colonialism
description: The stark sight of a western-style military outpost in the middle of a whole lot of desert nothingness, where Waiting for the Barbarians begins, may remind cinephiles of the 1976 Valerio Zurlini film The Desert of the Tartars. Its unclear whether the director of this picture, Ciro Guerra, meant the scene as a homage to Zurlinis film, but he didnt even need to. As it happens, J.M. Coetzee, whose novel of the same name inspired this film, was likely influenced by Dino Buzzatis book The Tartar Steppe, the source for Tartars.

title: Song Without a Name Review: A Tragedy in the Peruvian Hillside
description: The Peruvian film Song Without a Name sets a dramatic mood with gorgeous black-and-white photography and an original guitar score. The story, loosely based on true events, begins in 1988 with Georgina (Pamela Mendoza), a Quechua woman who sells potatoes in the outer limits of Lima. She responds to a notice for a clinic that helps pregnant women like herself deliver babies. But in the moments after she gives birth, her child is taken from her.

title: River City Drumbeat Review: A Communitys Pulse Proves Strong
description: Early on in the beautiful documentary River City Drumbeat, two leaders from the River City Drum Corp teach elementary school students in Kentucky a drum lesson. Albert Shumake, a new father who has been involved with the corp since his childhood, inspires students by bringing them back to their elemental beginnings. He reminds the class that the first sound they heard was their mothers heartbeat. As he speaks, his mentor Nardie White accompanies him on a drum, following Shumakes lead with a solid and simple beat.

title: Psychomagic, a Healing Art Review: Introducing Surrealist Therapy
description: For almost 70 years, the Chilean-born artist Alejandro Jodorowsky has been the utility infielder of lowercase-s surrealism. Hes a performer, graphic novelist, poet and, most prominently, a cult filmmaker. With the documentary Psychomagic, a Healing Art, he introduces the world to the work he has been involved in since the 70s.

title: Howard Review: A Lyricists Life Cut Short
description: Two years ago, T: The New York Times Style Magazine published the photographs of more than a hundred of the citys artists who had died of H.I.V./AIDS  a shocking record of creativity cut short and careers unrealized.

title: Money for the Postal Service? The Checks in the Mail
description: Democrats fight to fund the Postal Service, as Chicago becomes the latest city to decide students shouldnt return for in-person classes. Its Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

title: House Democrats seek better rates on loans to cities and states.
description: Rashida Tlaib, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and other House Democrats signed on to a letter urging the Federal Reserve to do more to support state and local governments, adding to criticism that the central bank is being too cautious in some of the programs it set up to help the economy during the pandemic.

title: As French President Visits Beirut, Lebanese Ask Where Their Leaders Are
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Visiting a neighborhood ravaged by this weeks giant explosion in Beiruts port, the president looked residents in the eye, vowed to send food and pursue a new political initiative, expressed sorrow for the lives lost and shoved aside a bodyguard to give a woman a hug.

title: In Tennessee, Bill Hagerty Wins Senate Primary
description: [Follow the DNC Live: Bidens speech, schedule, start time, streaming and more.]

title: In Richmond, Black Dance Claims a Space Near Robert E. Lee
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Janine Bell lived in Richmond for 35 years without visiting Monument Avenue. But that changed in July, when Ms. Bell threw a gathering honoring Emmett Till under the shadow of a statue of Robert E. Lee.

title: Lawmakers Aim to Prevent Trump From Bypassing Ban on Armed Drone Sales
description: WASHINGTON  A bill that Democratic and Republican senators introduced on Thursday would ban the sale of advanced armed drones to any nation that is not a close ally of the United States, according to lawmakers and congressional aides.

title: Hawa Abdi, Doctor Who Aided Thousands in Somalia, Dies at 73
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Hawa Abdi, a doctor and human rights activist who safeguarded the lives of tens of thousands of Somalis during years of war, famine and displacement, died on Wednesday at her home in Mogadishu, the Somali capital. She was 73.

title: For many workers, getting traction in the job market may require new skills.
description: With rising concerns that temporary layoffs are turning into permanent job losses, economists worry what this will mean for workers at the bottom rungs of the labor market  those with the fewest skills and the lowest pay.

title: As unemployment benefits began to run out, a freelance job came just in time.
description: For Curtis Hoover, the freelance designing gig came just in time. His regular state unemployment benefits had run out, as had the weekly $600 supplement that Congress approved to help jobless workers make it through the pandemic. He was still eligible for payments under an emergency extension of benefits for 13 weeks, but the clock was ticking on that assistance as well.

title: My Name Is Karen. What Can I Do About the Meme?
description: I am one of the many women who now find our name used as an insult or shorthand for an obnoxious, entitled, occasionally racist creature who demands to speak to the manager or calls the police for no good reason. I know this is not the biggest problem. But it really hurts me, especially since I try not to exhibit the behaviors associated with the insult. How should I respond when I hear someone being called a Karen? Ignore it, defend myself or change my name?

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, were sharing things were eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a five-bedroom in Greenwich, Conn., and a three-bedroom in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in Randall Manor, on the Upper West Side and in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Staten Island
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: New Students Show Diversity of U.C.s Freshman Class
description: Good morning.

title: Use These 18 Images to Inspire Your Own Short Story
description: Do you enjoy writing short stories or other works of fiction? How do you find inspiration for what you write?

title: He Spent 26 Years in a Chinese Prison. Then He Was Cleared of Murder.
description: A Chinese court on Wednesday exonerated a man who had spent more than 26 years in prison for the murder of two boys, a striking sign of the deep flaws in Chinas criminal justice system, and new, if halting, efforts at reform.

title: Organizing Your Face Masks
description: Roughly 80 percent of Americans say they wear face masks when they expect to be within 6 feet of other people, according to recent national surveys. Thats a lot of face masks.

title: Video Shows Beirut Bride at the Moment of the Blast
description: Just as Israa Seblani was posing for her wedding video, an explosion tore through the city  leaving more than 135 dead and thousands injured.

title: Shes Been a Force for Change in Ballet. The World Is Catching Up.
description: On May 29, four days after George Floyd was killed by the Minneapolis police, Theresa Ruth Howard posted a call to action on Instagram:

title: Snap will make a major effort to register first-time voters.
description: Snap, the company behind the popular social media app Snapchat, is planning a major push to register first-time voters within its app and to guide them through the ballot process ahead of the election on November 3.

title: Everyones lockdown obsession with Animal Crossing lifts Nintendos profits to $1 billion.
description: It didnt just seem like everyone spent their lockdown playing Animal Crossing  they really were.

title: Sweatpants Forever: How the Fashion Industry Collapsed
description: Even before the pandemic, it had started to unravel. What happens now that no one has a reason to dress up?

title: In Poland, the Rainbow Flag Is Wrapped Up in a Broader Culture War
description: When President Andrzej Duda of Poland was sworn in on Thursday for a second term in office after a bitterly divisive campaign in which he rallied support by targeting homosexuality as a threat to the nation, he looked out over the floor of Parliament to find a sea of color.

title: Dozens Charged in Hong Kong for Taking Part in Tiananmen Protest
description: Two dozen democracy advocates in Hong Kong were charged on Thursday with taking part in an annual vigil honoring the victims of the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests, the latest sign of the aggressive clampdown on dissent in the semiautonomous Chinese territory.

title: Credit card debt plunges, driving a decline in overall household debt.
description: Household debt fell in the second quarter as consumers stuck at home because of the coronavirus pandemic spent less on their credit cards, based on a new report from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: Gannett and Tribune newspaper chains see subscriber growth amid plunging advertising.
description: Gannett and Tribune Publishing, two of the last remaining publicly traded newspaper chains, both reported impressive subscription growth alongside plummeting advertising sales during the second quarter of this year, which was dominated by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: This Years Must-Have Back-to-School Item: Masks for Children
description: Fall is drawing near, and right on schedule, ads offering discounts on backpacks, notebooks and pencils are beginning to pop up on television and online.

title: Ava DuVernay Wins the Gish Prize
description: The Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize, one of the most generous arts honors in the United States, has been awarded to the filmmaker and activist Ava DuVernay, who has worked to amplify the voices of women and people of color in Hollywood.

title: The Tax Collector Review: Street Gangs and Family Values
description: Love. Honor. Loyalty. Family. The Tax Collector would have you believe its about all these things, as if slapping nouns on the screen (partly in cursive, no less) will convince us theres a higher purpose to the bloodletting and viciousness that follow. But weve all seen The Sopranos, and we wont get fooled again.

title: Even Asymptomatic People Carry the Coronavirus in High Amounts
description: Of all the coronaviruss qualities, perhaps the most surprising has been that seemingly healthy people can spread it to others. This trait has made the virus difficult to contain, and continues to challenge efforts to identify and isolate infected people.

title: What Is a Museum? A Dispute Erupts Over a New Definition
description: LONDON  Museums are having an identity crisis.

title: ViacomCBS takes a pandemic hit, with ad revenue falling 27 percent.
description: The coronavirus pandemic wiped out a large portion of ViacomCBSs advertising business and its box-office take in the second quarter, the company reported Thursday. ViacomCBS owns CBS, Nickelodeon, MTV, Showtime and the Paramount film studios. The companys ad revenue in the United States fell 24 percent to $1.7 billion, and its theatrical business dropped a staggering 98 percent from the same time last year, to $3 million. Total sales fell 12 percent to $6.2 billion, and profit was halved to $478 million.

title: She Was Pregnant With Twins During Covid. Why Did Only One Survive?
description: In March, with the coronavirus lockdown in full swing, Chrissy Sample was feeling anxious. Furloughed from her job and stuck at home with her 8-year-old son, she was also pregnant with twins, who were due in mid-July. Although she often felt immobilized by an intense pain in her legs and lower abdomen, her doctor regularly told her these feelings were normal.

title: New York Attorney General Sues N.R.A. and Seeks Its Closure
description: New Yorks attorney general issued an existential challenge to the National Rifle Association on Thursday, arguing in a lawsuit that years of runaway corruption and misspending demanded the dissolution of the nations most powerful gun rights lobby.

title: Whatever Happened to Arda Turan?
description: ISTANBUL  In the end, the question feels inappropriate. A little ridiculous, even. Arda Turan is sitting on the terrace of an impossibly lavish hotel, picking at a platter of fat grapes and sweet oranges and slices of fresh watermelon. The Bosporus shimmers a perfect blue. The sky is bright and glorious and it stretches all the way to Asia.

title: Now You Are Going to Die: Beirut Bride Recounts Moment of Blast
description: Israa Seblanis long white veil trailed behind her. She gazed downward as the camera captured her smile and panned to her train, draped around her feet in a lacy circle. She was just hours away from her wedding ceremony.

title: NBCUniversal Pushes Out Chairman of NBC Entertainment
description: NBCUniversal, the media giant owned by the cable operator Comcast, has pushed out the leader of its network entertainment group amid a pending investigation into claims of workplace harassment.

title: Diana Russell, Who Studied Violence Against Women, Dies at 81
description: Diana E.H. Russell, a leading feminist activist and scholar who popularized the term femicide to refer to the misogynist killing of women, and to distinguish these killings from other forms of homicide, died on July 28 at a medical facility in Oakland, Calif. She was 81.

title: A Prominent News Media Critic Is Starting a News Outlet of His Own
description: Over the last 15 years, Ken Doctor has made his living as a critic of the news industry. A onetime media executive who started out as a publisher and editor of an alt weekly, Mr. Doctor regularly warns against hedge-fund ownership of news outlets in a column he writes for Harvard Universitys Nieman Journalism Lab. Media companies hire him as a consultant, and he is often quoted in articles on the dismal state of local news coverage in America.

title: The Fed moves closer to a new way to get people their money faster.
description: The Federal Reserve Board has unanimously approved a system to support instant payments that could help cash-strapped consumers receive money transfers more quickly, allowing them to avoid overdrafts and payday-lender borrowing.

title: Wine Joins the 2020 Debate Over Privilege and Justice
description: In this topsy-turvy year of the Covid-19 pandemic and a national uproar over politics and racial injustice, few things are immune from the widespread cultural re-evaluation.

title: Iran Envoy Brian Hook, a Survivor on Trumps Team, to Quit
description: Brian Hook, the State Departments special envoy for Iran and one of the few national security officials to survive the turmoil in the foreign policy team through most of President Trumps term, is stepping down from his post, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced on Thursday.

title: Hurricane Forecast: One of the Most Active Seasons on Record
description: Following a record number of Atlantic Ocean storms over the past two months, including five that struck the United States, government scientists on Thursday updated their forecast for the remainder of the hurricane season, saying it was likely to be extremely active.

title: The Cult of the Tech Genius
description: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

title: Capital One will pay $80 million over hack.
description: Capital One has agreed to pay $80 million to settle federal bank regulators claims that it lacked proper cybersecurity protocols, more than a year after a Seattle-based software engineer hacked into a cloud server and stole customers social security numbers, bank account information and credit card applications, regulators said Thursday.

title: Star Trek: Lower Decks Review: Life as Phaser Fodder
description: Comedy. The final frontier.

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Have you heard of the Sealey Challenge? Started in 2017 by the poet Nicole Sealey, the exercise invites people to read more poetry by setting a specific goal: 31 books in 31 days throughout the month of August. If that sounds appealing, and you dont mind starting a few days late, you might jump in with Concordance, the latest collection by the estimable Susan Howe, which is one of nine new books we recommend this week.

title: Experiencing War Far From the Battlefield
description: It has been a long time since I enjoyed a book as much as I did LOVE IN THE BLITZ (Harper/HarperCollins, 496 pp., $28.99). Of the hundreds of books about World War II that Ive read, this is one of the best. I would welcome the author, Eileen Alexander, as a fresh new voice, but for the fact that she has been dead for nearly 50 years.

title: 3 Bon Apptit Journalists of Color Leave the Magazines Video Series
description: Two months after Bon Apptits top editor resigned under pressure amid complaints of racial insensitivity, three journalists of color said they would no longer participate in the magazines popular video series.

title: The Hottest New Label? U.S.P.S.
description: The U.S. Postal Service has been financially besieged for years, and unless Congress acts, the independent agency could run out of money by 2021. Now, there are calls on social media to save, or at least support, the U.S.P.S. by shopping its surprisingly wide variety of goods on its online store.

title: Contain Your Childrens Clutter
description: Children can be messy, but interior designers have some suggestions on setting up space to contain the worst of the clutter.

title: L.A. Mayor Threatens Crackdown on House Parties
description: Eric M. Garcetti, the mayor of Los Angeles, said that he was considering cutting the power to homes and businesses which host parties or large gatherings despite public health guidelines.

title: Gov. Mike DeWine of Ohio Tests Positive, Then Negative, for Coronavirus
description: Gov. Mike DeWine tested negative for the coronavirus hours after a positive rapid-result test had prevented him from welcoming President Trump to Ohio on Thursday, a whiplash reversal that reflected the nations increasingly complex state of testing.

title: 7 Things to Do This Weekend
description: In April, the Public Theater suspended its Shakespeare in the Park season for the first time, a move as disheartening as it was responsible. One production has since re-emerged in a new form, a Richard II starring Andr Holland and adapted for radio by the director Saheem Ali. But if youre missing the Delacortes visual pleasures, PBS, through its Great Performances series, has made last summers exuberant Much Ado About Nothing available on its website into September (it will also air the play on Aug. 14; check local listings).

title: Michelle Obama Says She Is Dealing With Low-Grade Depression
description: Michelle Obama said this week that she was experiencing low-grade depression and seemed to suggest that it was because of a combination of quarantine, racial unrest and the Trump administrations response to the pandemic.

title: Fewer Hip Fractures May Reflect a Drop in Smoking Rates
description: The incidence of hip fracture has decreased steadily over the past 40 years, but a new analysis suggests that new osteoporosis drugs have made only a small contribution to the trend.

title: A Killer Party Review: The Case of the Online Musical
description: I used to have high standards for new musicals. Relevance, craft and a reason for being were traits I looked for but often found lacking. Now that were in lockdown, Im just happy to see talented people working on anything that doesnt actively make me wish they werent.

title: Former Saudi Official Accuses the Crown Prince of Trying to Kill Him
description: BEIRUT  A former top Saudi intelligence official publicly accused Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman on Thursday of sending a team of agents to Canada to kill him.

title: Chat Group Becomes Target of Moscows Wrath as Security Crackdown Widens
description: MOSCOW  When a group of young Russians set up a chat group on social media nearly three years ago, they called themselves the Club of Plant Lovers, creating an innocuous gathering place for online discussion about their hobbies, university studies and sometimes politics.

title: Enrico Navarra, Art World Visionary, Is Dead at 67
description: Enrico Navarra, a gallerist, collector and art-book publisher with a visionary instinct who promoted artists, especially Jean-Michel Basquiat, before the rest of the art world had fully appreciated the importance of their work, died on July 21 in Le Muy, France. He was 67.

title: What Makes Kiarostami a Modern Master? Start Here
description: The Iranian director Abbas Kiarostami is widely regarded as one of the great modern filmmakers, but if you discovered him at a particular peak of his international recognition  when he shared the top prize at the Cannes Film Festival in 1997 for Taste of Cherry  you might have been baffled. Taste of Cherry follows an enigmatic driver who picks up passengers on the outskirts of Tehran. He plans to commit suicide, he says, and needs someone to bury him. For viewers unfamiliar with Kiarostami, watching more than an hour of such conversations was perplexing, even tedious.

title: Afghan War Casualty Report: August 2020
description: At least 117 pro-government forces and 37 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week, as peace talks continued to stall and Taliban forces waged targeted attacks on security forces. The deadliest attack took place in Baghlan Province, where the Taliban attacked Baghlan-e-Markazi District, killing four police officers and 12 pro-government militia members. Three outposts fell to the insurgents. Earlier in the week, in Balkh Province, new members of a military convoy were traveling to Dawlat Abad District from Mazar-e-Sharif when a roadside bomb exploded near a Humvee in the Yakhdan village of the district. Eight N.D.S. officers and two soldiers were killed, and two others were wounded. Days later, in the same province, a car full of explosives was detonated close to a commando unit in Balkh District, killing two commandos and eight civilians, while wounding an additional 20 commandos and 45 civilians. The explosion destroyed many nearby houses and the Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack.

title: Here's What Extreme Heat Looks Like: Profoundly Unequal
description: Earth is overheating. This year is poised to be one of the hottest ever. Millions are already feeling the pain, but the agony of extreme heat is profoundly unequal across the globe.

title: Suspension Lifted of Georgia Student Who Posted Photos of Crowded Hall
description: The widely circulated photo from North Paulding High School in Dallas, Ga., showed students crowded into a packed hallway on their first day back to classes since the coronavirus outbreak shuttered schools in the spring. Few were wearing masks, and there was little sign of social distancing. Then on Day 2, there was another.

title: Martin Peretz, on Israeli-Palestinian Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Racism Is Pervasive and Systemic at Canadas Museum of Human Rights, Report Says
description: TORONTO  Black and Indigenous employees say they were disparaged. Female employees say they were sexually harassed. Guides say their managers instructed them to block off an exhibit on same-sex marriage during tours for religious schools.

title: Some Wedding Vendors Face Fallout After Speaking Up on Social Issues
description: In June, the photographer Shakira Rochelle started taking photographs of Black Lives Matter protesters in her hometown Cincinnati. She shared the images and other supportive B.L.M. content on her personal Instagram account. Shortly, thereafter she received a text from a couple who had hired her to photograph their wedding.

description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Edmund White Thinks Most People Misread Lolita
description: [The Best Books of 2020: View our full list.]

title: Needed: A Safe Vaccine, Masks and Face Shields
description: To the Editor:

title: A 4th Presidential Debate? Commission Says No to Trump
description: Members of the Commission on Presidential Debates on Thursday rejected the Trump campaigns request for changes to the fall debate schedule, declining to shift the debates earlier or add a fourth debate to the calendar.

title: With Old Allies Turning Against Her, Birx Presses On Against the Coronavirus
description: WASHINGTON  As Dr. Deborah L. Birx was taking heat from both President Trump and Speaker Nancy Pelosi this week, the Democratic governor of Kentucky spoke up in her defense.

title: Why Influencers Wont Stop Partying Anytime Soon
description: In late July, dozens of social media stars flocked to the Hype House, a Hollywood Hills mansion where several top TikTok creators live, for a birthday party. The dcor was glittery and pink, with balloons and silver streamers strewn about. Hello Kitty strobe lights pulsed over a crowded dance floor.

title: After a Lull, the Number of Migrants Trying to Enter the U.S. Has Soared
description: NOGALES, Mexico  Illegal migration along the southwest border of the United States has surged after a period of stagnation, as economic hardship, made worse by the pandemic, has driven thousands northward seeking work.

title: Violence at Rikers at an All-Time High Despite Citys Promise to Curb It
description: Five years ago, the city entered a landmark legal settlement with federal prosecutors, promising to stamp out the culture of violence inside its jail complex on Rikers Island, a place where officers regularly used excessive force on inmates.

title: Top Equestrians Accused of Sex Abuse in Lawsuits
description: The equestrian worlds biggest kingmaker, George Morris, an Olympian who was barred for life from the sport one year ago, is now facing lawsuits by two people who said he raped them as teenagers.

title: For Three Suffragists, a Monument Well Past Due
description: Across the country, monuments honoring racist figures are being defaced and toppled. In New Yorks Central Park, one statue is taking shape that aims to amend not only racial but also gender disparities in public art: A 14-foot-tall bronze monument of Susan B. Anthony, Sojourner Truth and Elizabeth Cady Stanton, three of the more prominent leaders in the nationwide fight for womens right to vote.

title: New Unemployment Claims Decline, but Remain Alarmingly High
description: The government reported on Thursday that nearly 1.2 million workers filed new claims for state unemployment benefits last week. It was the lowest weekly total since March, but signaled the continuing damage that the pandemic is inflicting on the labor market.

title: Outages Pile On Misery for 1.4 Million Coping With Pandemic
description: Dozens of people forced to work from home because of the coronavirus lined up outside a library in a Connecticut suburb on Thursday, desperate for internet and a place to charge their laptops.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

title: Ubers Revenue Craters, as Deliveries Surge in Pandemic
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Uber is synonymous around the world with ride hailing. But as the coronavirus pandemic shows few signs of loosening its grip, the company may become more closely associated with another business: delivery.

title: The Coronavirus Is New, but Your Immune System Might Still Recognize It
description: Eight months ago, the new coronavirus was unknown. But to some of our immune cells, the virus was already something of a familiar foe.

title: Tennessee Democratic Primary Election Results: Fifth Congressional District
Tennessee Primary Election Results: Fourth Congressional District
Tennessee Primary Election Results: Second Congressional District
Tennessee Primary Election Results: Eighth Congressional District
Live: Tennessee State Primary Election Results 2020
description: Detailed results and maps from the Tennessee primary election.

title: Tennessee U.S. Senate Primary Election Results
Tennessee Primary Election Results: Ninth Congressional District
Tennessee Primary Election Results: First Congressional District
What Megan Fox Taught Me About the Power of Subversive Girls
description: One freshman biology lab, I was grouped with an OK guy and the only out girl in my grade. We were supposed to be dissecting worms.

title: Trump Reinstates Tariff on Canadian Aluminum
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump announced Thursday that he was reimposing a 10 percent tariff on Canadian aluminum to help struggling American producers, a step that is likely to incite retaliation and worsen ties with Canada just one month after the countries new trade deal went into effect.

title: Inspired by Memories and Remedies, Earthy Home Scents From Loewe
description: Of all the senses, smell has a unique and scientifically proven ability to transport us to an earlier moment or chapter in our lives. For Jonathan Anderson, 35, the creative director of both Loewe and his namesake line, the earthy, green scent of tomato leaves will forever bring him back to his boyhood in Magherafelt, a small town in Northern Ireland surrounded by verdant lowlands and rolling hills. As a kid, I loved greenhouses, and ours always smelled of tomato leaves, he says. Its a strange, sharp smell, different from the fruits skin.

title: Tourist Posing With 200-Year-Old Sculpture Breaks Its Toes
description: The Austrian tourist who got a bit too close to Napoleons younger sister has apologized.

title: Amid Dire Jobless Numbers, Small-Business Relief Program Nears End
description: In early April, three weeks after Connecticut issued shutdown orders, Ken Bodenstein borrowed $148,000 from the federal government to help cover payroll expenses at the Westport day care center he runs with his wife, Kristen.

title: At the Census Bureau, a Technical Memo Raises Alarms Over Politics
description: WASHINGTON  A Census Bureau memorandum on creating a state-by-state estimate of people illegally in the country is raising new fears of a politicized census  this time involving the population totals that will be used to reapportion the House of Representatives next year.

title: M.L.B. Tightens Virus Protocols Again in Wake of Outbreaks
description: With the St. Louis Cardinals sidelined by a raft of positive coronavirus tests  and the Miami Marlins playing with a reconstructed roster after their own outbreak caused the league to reshuffle schedules in late July  Major League Baseball has again tightened its health protocols in an effort to safely navigate the rest of its shortened season.

title: Coming Next: The Greater Recession
description: One pretty good forecasting rule for the coronavirus era has been to take whatever Trump administration officials are saying and assume that the opposite will happen. When President Trump declared in February that the number of cases would soon go close to zero, you knew that a huge pandemic was coming. When Vice President Mike Pence insisted in mid-June that there isnt a coronavirus second wave, a giant surge in new cases and deaths was clearly imminent.

title: Stimulus, Beirut, National Seashores: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The Latest U.S. Tool to Fight Election Meddling: Text Messages
description: WASHINGTON  The United States government on Thursday became, for a brief moment, one of the biggest and perhaps most annoying telemarketers in Russia.

title: Debt, Debt, Goose
description: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

title: Beirut Residents Help Clean Up Debris From Explosion
description: People in Beirut, Lebanon, cleared the rubble from their streets after an explosion earlier in the week.

title: Homeland Security Chief Defends Deployments in Portland
description: WASHINGTON  Chad F. Wolf, the acting secretary of homeland security, on Thursday defended his deployment of tactical agents to face protesters in Portland, Ore., after the standoff prompted accusations that the operation had politicized his agency.

title: Family Mourns Beirut Emergency Worker Killed in Explosion
description: A wedding band accompanied the funeral of Sahar Fares, an emergency medical worker who had been engaged to be married. Ms. Fares was one of 145 people killed on Tuesday in the explosion at the citys port.

title: Elizabeth Warren Says Child Care Is Key to Bringing the Economy Back
description: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. Im Lisa Lerer, your host.

title: The World Can Still Be Destroyed in a Flash
description: The nuclear weapons dropped over Hiroshima and Nagasaki 75 years ago this week wreaked a devastation never before seen in human warfare. Yet they were firecrackers compared with the nuclear weapons that were soon developed  bombs, warheads, shells, torpedoes and other devices capable of vaporizing the human race in an apocalyptic flash.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Some European countries are seeing resurgences of the coronavirus, setting off fears of a potential second wave. Among them are Germany and France  this week they both reported their highest numbers of new daily cases in months.

title: Paramedic Who Died in Beirut Explosion Is a Symbol of Lebanons Grief
description: On Thursday, Sahar Faress fianc and family gave her the wedding party she will never have.

title: As Jobs Report Looms, White House and Congress Say Stark Divisions Remain Over Stimulus Plan
description: WASHINGTON  Top Democrats and the White House clashed anew on Thursday over an economic recovery package as a jobs report loomed over stalled negotiations on the plan, raising the stakes of an agreement even as a compromise appeared to be nowhere in sight.

title: Trump, Facing Headwinds in Ohio, Talks Up Economy in Campaign Swing
description: President Trump traveled Thursday to the crucial battleground of Ohio, hoping to highlight efforts to bolster the economy after the damage done by the spread of the coronavirus and to announce new executive orders to make drug prices more affordable.

title: Workers at Philadelphia Museum of Art Vote to Join Union
description: The Philadelphia Museum of Art became home to one of the largest museum unions in the country on Thursday as 89 percent of eligible employees voted to join the American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees.

title: Sri Lanka Election Hands Rajapaksa Family a Bigger Slice of Control
description: President Gotabaya Rajapaksas governing party won a majority of Sri Lankas parliamentary seats, the Election Commission announced Friday, bringing the president a step closer in his quest to amend the Constitution and expand his executive power.

title: I Was a Little Scared: Inside Americas Reopening Schools
description: INDIANAPOLIS  It was the purple Powerade that convinced her.

title: The U.S. Lifted Its Advisory Against Traveling Abroad. What Does That Mean?
description: The State Department lifted its blanket advisory warning American citizens against traveling abroad on Thursday, nearly five months after the department had issued the Level 4 do not travel warning  its highest advisory  against all international travel as the coronavirus spread.

title: Judge Dismisses G.O.P. Suit to End Proxy Voting in House During Pandemic
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge on Thursday dismissed a suit filed by congressional Republicans against Speaker Nancy Pelosi that sought to block the House of Representatives from using a proxy-voting system to allow for remote legislating during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Bill Hagerty Wins Tough Tennessee Primary With Trumps Endorsement
description: The Tennessee Senate Republican primary may have taken a competitive turn in its final weeks, but Bill Hagerty proved that for red-state candidates in the Trump era, there are still few things more valuable than the endorsement of Donald J. Trump himself.

title: Move Like a Snail
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Even in the middle of a pandemic, there are people who like to party, especially as a way to celebrate the coming weekend.

title: Trump Targets WeChat and TikTok, in Sharp Escalation With China
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration has announced sweeping restrictions on two popular Chinese social media networks, TikTok and WeChat, a sharp escalation of its confrontation with China that is likely to be met with retaliation.

title: Could This Be the Last Time We See Our Dad?
description: New York Citys streets and restaurants were still packed in early March, as Gov. Andrew Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio argued over methodology, logistics and the economic repercussions of whether to shut the city down to curb the spread of the coronavirus.

title: Beirut, Coronavirus, TikTok Restrictions: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Mumbai Put Female Figures on Traffic Signals. Some Women Are Not Impressed.
description: At one of the most prominent street crossings in Mumbai, the little people in the signal lights have swapped their straight-legged trousers for triangular frocks.

title: Arson Suspected in Denver Fire That Killed 5 From Senegal
description: The president of Senegal on Thursday mourned the deaths of five members of a family of immigrants from his country who were killed one day earlier in a house fire in Denver that the authorities said appeared to have been set intentionally.

title: Quotation of the Day: Enormous Biker Rally Defies Public Opposition
description: We are either going to be a great success story or failure. I truly believe it could not have been stopped.

title: When Marriage Is Just Another Overhyped Nightclub
description: People treat you differently when you are steadily single. Not everyone, not all the time, not always overtly, not necessarily unkindly. They ask why no one has snatched you up, offer to set you up on blind dates, seat you at the singles table at formal events. They extend last-minute invitations to dinner parties when someone else has bailed.

title: Smile, Australia. Look at Whats Flourishing Despite the Pandemic.
description: I was going to write this week about what the world should take away from Melbournes resurgent outbreak and Stage 4 lockdown, but then I thought: Maybe we need an escape?

title: The Mom and Pop Factory With an Atomic Secret
description: Its rare these days to be a small and successful manufacturer in New York City. And perhaps even rarer for a family-owned business to pivot its operations several times in moments of national need  including participating in a mysterious and ultra-top-secret military contract that redefined modern warfare.

title: Whats on TV Friday: Sweet Bean and Jojo Rabbit
description: SWEET BEAN (2016) Stream on Mubi. Sentaro (Masatoshi Nagase)  a Japanese baker who serves pancake-like pastries called dorayaki  is struggling, and appears perpetually grumpy. Then along comes Tokue (Kirin Kiki), the fairy godmother of an, the sweet red bean paste in the center of dorayaki. Seemingly out of nowhere, Tokue approaches Sentaros bakery and tells him she wants to work for him. Sentaro is hesitant at first. But Tokues an has something special, he realizes, and the wisdom she has to give is equally magical. In his review for The New York Times, Glenn Kenny wrote that the movie, beautifully shot and acted, earns its ultimate sense of hope by confronting real heartbreak head-on, and with compassion. Sweet Bean, based on a novel by Durian Sukegawa, was written and directed by Naomi Kawase, and it debuted at the 2015 Cannes Film Festival.

title: Jimmy Fallon Sends Thoughts and Prayers to the N.R.A.
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous nights highlights that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Many of us are stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Theyre Children at Risk of Abuse, and Their Caseworkers Are Stuck Home
description: TOLLHOUSE, Calif.  In February, the child abuse hotline for Tollhouse, a small community in the Central Valley, received the first of several tips raising urgent concerns about the well-being of twin infant boys.

title: Brooks Koepka Is Here to Win Majors, Not Friends
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When Brooks Koepka teed off in the quiet calm of Thursday morning, he figured he was not just a contender, but a favorite to win the P.G.A. Championship.

title: Work It Review: Freestyling Through Senior Year
description: In the middling dance movie Work It, now on Netflix, Quinn (Sabrina Carpenter) is a straight-A senior desperate to attend her dream university, Duke. So desperate, in fact, that when her college interviewer expresses an appreciation for dance, Quinn pretends its her passion, too. To keep up the ruse, she cobbles together a ragtag hip-hop troupe and starts to train. Shes a quick learner; how hard can it be to keep a rhythm?

title: Authors Distill Their Writing Advice to Just a Few Words
description: It has been nearly 20 years since the night in a newspaper office in Delhi when I came across a copy of a fax V.S. Naipaul had sent in response to a reporter asking for his rules of writing. (Avoid the abstract; always go for the concrete.) I found those rules useful. In recent years, I have had a mantra of my own: Write every day, and walk every day. A modest goal of 150 words daily and mindful walking for 10 minutes.

title: News Quiz: Beirut, TikTok, Census Bureau
description: Did you follow the headlines this week?

title: Milwaukee Police Chief Demoted After Questions Over Protest Response
description: Alfonso Morales, the police chief of Milwaukee, was demoted on Thursday after an oversight board questioned the polices performance under his leadership, including the recent use of tear gas and pepper spray against protesters.

title: At Europes Illegal Parties, the Virus Is the Last Thing on Anyones Mind
description: Nightclubs around Europe are shut. But that doesnt mean the continents party people are staying home.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 100 Years Later, These Activists Continue Their Ancestors Work
description: A new generation of activists traces its ancestry and inspiration to key figures in the suffrage movement.

title: Weekly Health Quiz: Coronavirus Symptoms, Memory and Talking to Strangers
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: How I Got My Daughter to Take Her A.D.H.D. Pill
description: My 10-year-old daughter Norah didnt want to take her medication for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder a few months ago. Not that this was the first time shed told us no. Surely it wasnt. It really depended on the day. Some days she took it without complaint, and other days she refused.

title: Three New Memoirs Offer a Glimpse Into the Writers Mind
description: GREAT DEMON KINGS A Memoir of Poetry, Sex, Art, Death, and Enlightenment By John Giorno 351 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $28.

title: A Birthday at the Cemetery
description: We had barely clicked our seatbelts into place when my mother said, Do you mind if we stop at the cemetery?

title: What Sonia Sotomayor Told a 10-Year-Old Girl
description: MIAMI  Last February, before social distancing became a reality for us all, I was able to interview Justice Sonia Sotomayor for my Contrapoder podcast. Among our small audience was Sophie McLoud, 10. The girl had a question for Justice Sotomayor, the first Latina Supreme Court justice in American history. Do you think a girl like me could become president of the United States? Sophie asked. Ill share the amazing answer that Justice Sotomayor gave Sophie later. For now, lets focus on the latest news.

title: Hot and Bothered: Four New Romance Novels
description: We reach for romance when illness strikes, when the world weighs too heavily, when our own joy is hard to find but we need to know its still out there somewhere. This summers crop of romance novels are about squaring up to hardship and finding something better on the other side.

title: New in Paperback: Around the World in 80 Trees and The Truths We Hold
description: THE GUEST BOOK, by Sarah Blake. (Flatiron, 512 pp., $17.99.) Welcome to old money, new heartbreak, big secrets and the kind of mouthwatering picnics nobody packs in real life, was how Elisabeth Egan began her review of this novel set on the Maine island where the Milton family summers. After a tragedy Egan did not see coming, a granddaughter makes a shocking discovery.

title: Living While Black in Lovecraft Country
description: Lovecraft Country, which debuts Aug. 16 on HBO, tells the intersecting stories of two Black families as they travel throughout the Jim Crow North confronting monsters  some fantastical (pale gray beasts called Elder Gods) and others that are no less horrific for being based in reality (racist sheriffs, predatory oligarchs).

title: Investors Cozy Up to Danish Stocks
description: Denmark is a place of hygge, happiness and  in the face of a global downturn  a high-performing stock market.

title: So What Does Trump Have Against TikTok?
description: The one thing my students all invariably know about China is that you cant use Facebook there, or YouTube or Google. For at least a decade, China has maintained strict control over the internet and aggressively blocked foreign tech platforms within its borders.

title: Gods, Monsters and H.P. Lovecrafts Uncanny Legacy
description: Lovecraft Country, premiering Aug. 16 on HBO, follows a Black family entangled in eldritch phenomena. Based on Matt Ruffs 2016 novel, the series is a sideways look at the terrors of Jim Crow America that nods to and reframes the work of H.P. Lovecraft, the widely cited if narrowly read pulp fiction writer from the early 20th century.

title: Im a Conservative Christian Environmentalist. No, Thats Not an Oxymoron.
description: Its been a long time coming, but some Republicans seem to have finally gotten serious about climate change. In June, a handful of senators rolled out a bipartisan climate change bill. It is co-sponsored by Debbie Stabenow, Democrat of Michigan, and Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina.

title: Did He Kill Neighbor to Become TikTok Famous, or Was It Self-Defense?
description: Zachary Latham and the Durham family were South Jersey neighbors who did not get along. Ultimately, their conflict turned fatal.

title: Canada to U.S. Visitors: Please Dont Sneak Across the Border
description: I was packing for my road trip from Colorado to Alberta, Canada, when the text came in from a gentleman Id been helping with groceries during the pandemic.

title: Why Im Obsessed With Patients Medical Bills
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: Lifestyles of the Rich and Reckless: Posh Pandemic Parties
description: A little more than two months ago, in the aftermath of Memorial Day weekend, New Yorkers of a certain caste indulged rounds of condescension directed at a set of anonymous partygoers in the Ozarks. The catalyst was the viral image of a pool party where people were grouped a shot glass width apart, none of them wearing masks.

title: lvaro Uribes Detention Deepens Colombias Divisions
description: BOGOT, Colombia  Former president lvaro Uribe has dominated Colombias political landscape for decades as the countrys most beloved  and most hated  politician.

title: Trump and His Allies Think They Know Who Counts
description: Over the last few years, the Trump administration has fought to shape the 2020 census to its political benefit and the benefit of the Republican Party. In 2018, it sought to introduce a citizenship question on the census itself, to reduce response rates among immigrant communities. Then, after that was rebuffed by the Supreme Court, it tried to exclude unauthorized immigrants altogether, in direct conflict with the Constitution, which calls on Congress to count the whole number of persons in each State. Now it wants to cut the census short and deliver it uncompleted  a last-ditch effort to rig the nations politics for the sake of its exclusionary political vision.

title: They Were Arrested During the Protests. Heres What Happened Next.
description: Anthony Mendez recalled how he had been held in a crowded cell for six hours after he was arrested during a protest, the first time that he had ever gone to a march. Clare Ramirez-Raftree said she ended up with welts on her wrists for days from the tight plastic handcuffs. And Patrick McElravey said police officers put him in a chokehold in Brooklyn.

title: She Fell in Love, and the Dog Approved
description: In June 2018, when Tara Harper told Frederick Rahr that she was going to drive eight hours round trip, from Dallas to Pasadena, Texas, to pick up an elderly and neglected German shepherd, she never imagined the man she had been seeing for just a few months would volunteer to join her. When he did, she figured he was just trying to score a few points with her.

title: Leaving New York: How to Choose the Right Suburb
description: For some New Yorkers, urban life is a phase, to be experienced between college and the birth of a first or second child. The question of moving to the suburbs is not whether, so much as when.

title: Abolish the Police? Those Who Survived the Chaos in Seattle Arent So Sure
description: SEATTLE  Faizel Khan was being told by the news media and his own mayor that the protests in his hometown were peaceful, with a block party atmosphere.

title: In a Wistful Age, Farmers Find a New Angle: Chore TV
description: PEACHAM, Vt.  The sweet smell of hay rose off the earth on a recent evening, as Morgan Gold strode across his farmyard in heavy boots. He crossed the paddock, scanning for new eggs, water levels, infected peck wounds, rips in the fence line.

title: For a Small Stable, Big Prizes Could Lie Ahead
description: How lucky is Jack Knowlton? Lucky enough to have the even-money favorite, Tiz the Law, in the 151st running of the Travers Stakes on Saturday in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., and with no real pressure to win it.

title: Why Black Workers Will Hurt the Most if Congress Doesnt Extend Jobless Benefits
description: When Congress expanded unemployment insurance this year to meet the staggering economic toll of the pandemic, it had one less-noticed effect: It made Americas fractured jobless benefits system more fair.

title: Beijing Launches Another Demolition Drive, This Time in Its Bucolic Suburbs
description: The people who would destroy the village came in the middle of the night last week. Hundreds of guards breached the wall surrounding the village and began banging on the doors of the 140 courtyard homes there, waking residents and handing them notices to get out.

title: A Star Went Supernova in 1987. Where Is It Now?
description: It was one of the great fireworks displays of recent cosmic history.

title: Summertime in the (Partly Reopened) City
description: For about four months, as the pandemic bore down on New York City, an island had been left practically deserted in New York Harbor.

title: A Season of Grief and Release: 5 Months of the Virus in New York City
description: The restaurant was empty, save for two other tables. Spoons slid through our dessert, split three ways. We were anxious but determined to enjoy it, somehow. It was March 10, and the coronavirus had just hit New York City. We laughed, but with worry in our brows and the preamble of panic in our eyes.

title: For P.O.W., Landmark Verdict Against North Korea Is Long-Overdue Justice
description: PYEONGTAEK, South Korea  He was only 17 when Chinese troops backing North Korea overran a hill being defended by his South Korean Army squad and took him prisoner in the early hours of Dec. 28, 1951.

title: Trump Vows to Issue Executive Orders if Coronavirus Relief Talks Collapse
description: This briefing has ended. Read live coronavirus updates here.

title: Where Do Republicans Go From Here?
description: Jonathan V. Last thinks President Trump is here forever. Last, the editor of The Bulwark, a conservative site thats been hostile to Trump, argues that if Trump loses in November, hell claim he was cheated out of the election. Hell force other Republicans to back up his claim. Hell get a TV show, hold rallies, be coy about running again in 2024.

title: Chinas exports rise despite the virus, surprising economists.
description: Chinas exports rose last month at their fastest pace so far this year, the countrys General Administration of Customs announced on Friday.

title: Denmark has one of the best-performing stock markets in the world this year.
description: Denmarks stock market is having a stellar year so far.

title: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Heres What Happened This Week
description: [Want to get New York Today by email? Heres the sign-up.]

title: A Warming World
description: In the past 60 years, every decade has been hotter than the last, and 2020 is on track to be among the hottest years yet. But the burden of extreme heat is not shared equally  its significantly worse for people at the bottom of the socioeconomic ladder.

title: Fate Kept Them Together
description: When Victoria Michelotti first saw Aln Weinfeld in October 2010, he was sitting at a Manhattan bar with another woman  his mother.

title: Long Chats Followed Their Alumni Reunion
description: Betsy Zeidman and David Kleeman were a year apart at Sidwell Friends School in Washington in the 1970s, though both were on the school newspaper and so knew each other casually. Their awareness of each other over the ensuing decades was limited to occasional Sidwell alumni updates.

title: After a Generation, 2 Families in the Same Place Again
description: A classic best-friends-boyfriend connection brought Danica Gould and John Stamatis together, in 2015, but it eventually emerged that their connections went back another generation. Just a coincidence? The couple isnt convinced.

title: A Running Mate Found in the Crowd
description: Alice Muglia and William Russo had been running in the same political circles since 2012, when she was working for the re-election of President Barack Obama and he was working in the White House for Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who is now the presumptive Democratic nominee.

title: Facebook Gaming Finally Clears Apple Hurdle, Arriving in App Store
description: For six months, Facebook tried to get Apple to approve its new Facebook Gaming app so it could be available in Apples App Store. Each time, Apple said no.

title: Firefighters Called to Duty Hours Before Their Wedding
description: Danielle Day was watching her bridesmaids get their hair and makeup done a few hours before her July 18 wedding when the alert came in.

title: A Missed Connection, Six Years Later
description: Caroline Anderson and Robert Parisot can point to the day they almost met in 2011. They were both students at Harvard Law School at the time, and Ms. Anderson, who was in her third year, was participating in Harvard Law Schools Ames Moot Court Competition, a competition for appellate brief writing and advocacy. Mr. Parisot, who was a first-year law student, had been assigned to attend as part of his classes.

title: Finally an Upgrade From the Training Rings
description: Two years ago, at the checkout counter of a five-and-dime store in Guerneville, Calif., Ted Boerner and Rabbi Oren Postrel looked down into the display case and saw rings in black velvet boxes for sale, at $7.99, $8.99 and $9.99.

title: A Little Birdie Gave Him the Scoop at the Zoo
description: Eric Wasserman Stern and Evan Michael Zuzik figure they have eaten more than a thousand scoops of ice cream together, at least.

title: Between Reps at the Gym, a Strong Connection
description: When Lauren Maillian joined the New York Sports Club in Harlem, her intention was to work out. Robert Palmer had the same desire.

title: Neither Could Have Imagined This Adventure
description: When the coronavirus forced Claire Benjamin and Henry Fineberg to rethink their original wedding plans, they decided to elope in Colorado, choosing June 27 as a new date for their nuptials. But as it turned out, that summer day brought enough snow and powerful winds to turn the couples ceremony into the kind of adventure they hadnt planned on.

title: Coronavirus Silences the Wonder Wheel
description: Denos Wonder Wheel, a 15-story signature feature of the Coney Island skyline, first spun to life in the wake of the Spanish flu pandemic a century ago. Now, as the coronavirus casts a growing pall over the storied amusement district, the family that owns the wheel says that the whirling behemoth will almost certainly go the entire season without carrying passengers for the first time in a hundred summers.

title: Jack Dorsey on Twitters Mistakes
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

title: Millions face eviction as pandemic relief measures end, researchers warn.
description: After the recent lapse of a federal supplement to unemployment payments, and with a patchwork of eviction moratoriums either at an end or set to expire soon, 30 million to 40 million tenants risk losing their homes in the coming months, according to a report released Friday by dozens of academic researchers and housing advocates.

title: Targeting WeChat, Trump Takes Aim at Chinas Bridge to the World
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  In China, WeChat does more than any app rightfully should. People use it to talk, shop, share photos, pay bills, get their news and send money.

title: Trump takes aim at WeChat, Chinas bridge to the world.
description: Late Thursday, the Trump administration issued an executive order that could pull WeChat, Chinas most important app, from Apple and Google stores across the world and prevent American companies from doing business with its parent company, Tencent. Light on details, the decree could prove cosmetic, crushing or something in between.

title: Why an Accurate Census Is So Important
description: Welcome to Poll Watch, our weekly look at polling data and survey research on the candidates, voters and issues that will shape the 2020 election.

title: Europes Last Dictator, Facing Re-Election, Is Increasingly in Peril
description: MINSK, Belarus  The man often described as Europes last dictator has never looked so shaky.

title: Power Outages Hit Manhattan and Queens as Utilities Face Storm Damage
description: Three days after a huge tropical storm swept through the New York City region and left more than a million people without power, much of Upper Manhattan was briefly plunged into darkness early Friday morning.
