description: When the Turkish lira plunged to a new low against the dollar and euro this month, Hakan Bulgurlu did not panic. This was not the first time that Mr. Bulgurlu, the chief executive of Arcelik, a Turkish maker of home appliances, had steered through a currency crisis.

title: Republican Convention: Best and Worst Moments From Mike Pence Night
description: Welcome to Opinions commentary for Night 3 of the Republican National Convention. In this special feature, Times Opinion writers rank the evening on a scale of 1 to 10: 1 means the night was a disaster for Republicans; 10 means it could lead to a big polling bump for the Trump-Pence ticket. Heres what our columnists and contributors thought of the event, which featured Richard Grenell, Lara Trump, Kellyanne Conway and Vice President Mike Pence.

title: The M.T.A.s Doomsday Budget Plan
description: [Want to get New York Today by email? Heres the sign-up.]

title: White House, Under Fire for Discouraging Coronavirus Testing, Says It Will Buy Millions of Test Kits
description: This briefing has ended. Read live coronavirus updates here.

title: On the Ground in Kenosha
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

title: A Perk for N.Y.s Richest Areas: First Dibs on Top Public Schools
description: On paper, Tiffani Torres looked like a strong candidate for one of New York Citys highest-performing, most selective public high schools. She had high test scores and excellent grades. I was a good fit for what the school was looking for, Tiffani said.

title: Soon, the Kitty Litter Will Come by Electric Truck
description: Going back years, you might have been able to spot a truck from the likes of FedEx and UPS, and more recently Amazon, that ran on electricity. But most of these were small, short test runs that left the internal-combustion status quo in place.

title: The Growing Power of Hurricanes
description: Hurricane Laura shares something in common with both Hurricane Florence, a 2018 storm that killed 52 Americans, and Hurricane Katrina, which struck Louisiana 15 years ago this week. All three changed from more typical hurricanes into severe ones in just a day or two.

title: Matthias & Maxime Review: Unsealed With a Kiss
description: There are some directors you wish would never grow up, and Xavier Dolan  a man whose fire hose of emotions could at times make you giddy  is one. Before he turned 27, with movies like Laurence Anyways (2013) and Mommy (2015), Dolan seemed to have decided that restraint was a dirty word and expressiveness his guiding principal.

title: All Together Now Review: A Song as a Source of Hope
description: There is a particular skill in presenting a character who is nearly flawless without turning her into a staid saint. In Brett Haleys sweet and scrappy teen Netflix drama All Together Now, Amber Appleton (Aulii Cravalho) checks so many boxes of trait perfection (she volunteers at a retirement community, teaches E.S.L. classes, etc.) that a worse film would become a hagiography. But Haleys directing has a gentility, and Cravalho (who was introduced to movie audiences as the title voice in Disneys Moana) gives Amber a visceral humanity that elevates the intermittently uneven screenplay.

title: Mr. Soul! Review: Televising the Revolution, With Great Songs
description: In one of the many remarkable archival clips in the documentary Mr. Soul!, a 20-something Al Green croons Love and Happiness on live TV. Seen in front of him in long shot are the bobbing heads of an enraptured audience. They form  as the writer Greg Tate describes in an interview  a sea of big, bold Afros.

title: You Cannot Kill David Arquette Review: Ready to Rumble (Again)?
description: When the admirably raw documentary You Cannot Kill David Arquette begins, its title subject is out of shape and recovering from a recent heart attack. His mental health and his recent sobriety both seem shaky, and his film career has not lived up to early promise. But its not acting that haunts David Arquettes dreams. Instead, he fantasizes about professional wrestling.

title: The Binge Review: Theyll Drink to That
description: Heres an equation for third-period math: Take Superbad, Booksmart, and, hell, any teen-party movie, add in a useless overarching conceit, subtract all originality. The result is The Binge, a new Hulu original that is only exceptional in its mind-numbing inanity.

title: Ghost Tropic Review: A Missed Stop and a Long Walk Home
description: This new movie from the Belgian filmmaker Bas Devos opens with a static shot of an apartments living room and its window. No one is there. The shot holds as the room goes from fully lit to completely dark. I see the time that has gone by, a woman says in voice-over. How would a stranger feel here?

title: Fatima Review: Blinded by the Light
description: Fatima is based on the life of Sister Lucia, who, as a girl in 1917, along with two of her cousins, claimed to have seen visions of the Virgin Mary in a field in Ftima, Portugal. Throngs of the curious flocked to the site. When observers reported seeing fantastical solar phenomena  a sighting called the Miracle of the Sun  it was treated as corroboration. The Roman Catholic Church deemed the apparitions worthy of belief in 1930.

title: Epicentro Review: They Are Cuba
description: The Austrian-born Hubert Sauper has made two remarkable  documentaries on colonialism, each employing a powerful central metaphor. Darwins Nightmare (2005) draws an analogy between foreign plunderers of Tanzania and an invasive species of fish. We Come as Friends (2015) compares the investors descending on South Sudan (and Saupers visit) to an onslaught from another planet.

title: Whats on TV Thursday: Madeas Farewell Play and Rising Phoenix
description: TYLER PERRYS MADEAS FAREWELL PLAY Stream on BET+. Last year, Tyler Perry threw on his gray wig, lipstick and thick, square glasses, and hit the road: He was going to retire his most famous character, Madea, but first he was taking her on a final tour. The show he presented, Madeas Farewell Play, covers familiar Madea territory: wisecracks, music and a plot built on a law school graduation that brings the family back together  comfort food for fans who stream this recorded version. That old broad has been good to me, so who knows  maybe one day Ill tell the story of Madea in the 70s and hire a real actress to play the role, Perry wrote in an essay in The New York Times last year. But the time of playing her has come to an end.

title: Made in Bangladesh Review: A Quiet Power in Collective Efforts
description: Made in Bangladesh opens with a close-up of a woman threading a sewing machine. As the closing credits begin, the sounds of a sewing machine return from that initial sequence; it may not be until that moment that you realize just how much the movie has taken you  minutely, step by step  through an arduous process.

title: How to Watch the Republican National Convention
description: After eight intense nights of programming, the 2020 conventions will come to an end on Thursday: President Trump will formally accept the Republican nomination, and the general election season will officially begin.

title: Whats That on the Mets Roof Garden? A Big, Beautiful Wall
description: A buff-and-gray stronghold of stone, steel and glass set against Central Park, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is designed to shut out pretty much everything the park represents. Its sealed off from weather and seasons, and natural change of any kind. The one part of the museum thats an exception is the Cantor Roof Garden. Open to the elements, its rain-washed and sun-washed year round.

title: The Elephants in the Room
description: Good morning and welcome to a special convention recap edition of On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics.

title: China Fires Missiles Into South China Sea, Sending U.S. a Message
description: China has fired a barrage of medium-range missiles across considerable distances into the South China Sea, Beijings latest move to demonstrate its strategic dominance and sovereignty over the disputed waters.

title: Entertainment Is Power in Push for Racial Justice
description: Want this delivered to your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

title: The Photographer Capturing Unvarnished Truths
description: WE PUT A kind of call out for cocks. And they brought them. Theyre beautiful. I mean, theyre extremely, extremely beautiful, says the photographer Heji Shin in the midst of her latest shoot, her first since the Covid-19 lockdown: large-format studio portraits  very sharp, very shiny  of bellicose roosters. Two prints from the series, titled Big Cocks, recently appeared in a group show at Galerie Buchholz in Berlin. Roosters have long been associated with masculinity (though, in fact, they dont have penises, Shin informs me); in an era in which violence tends to be systemic or tactical, she writes to me later, the short-lived outbursts of angry cock energy look Hellenistic and virile.

title: Welcome to the R.N.C.s Alternate Universe
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today free newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it every weekday.

title: What to Know About Californias Coronavirus Testing Expansion
description: Good morning.

title: German Automotive Giant Admits It Was a Nazi Accomplice
description: FRANKFURT  The auto parts maker Continental became the latest German company to issue a confessional study of its Nazi past Thursday, saying it was a pillar of the National Socialist armaments and war economy that employed around 10,000 slave laborers, often in inhumane conditions.

title: The wait for the $300 unemployment benefit can depend on a states computers.
description: Why have some states been able to move quickly to pay out the new $300-a-week unemployment benefit, while others expect the process to take weeks? In a word: technology.

title: After months of unemployment, back at work but not feeling secure.
description: Kris Fusco is finally back at work. That doesnt mean her coronavirus worries are behind her.

title: Powell Announces New Effort to Achieve Maximum Employment
description: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, unveiled a plan aiming to keep unemployment low while tolerating higher inflation.

title: Hurricane Laura Sweeps Through Gulf Coast
description: Hurricane Laura, one of the strongest U.S. storms on record, moved north through Louisiana after making landfall as a Category 4 storm early Thursday.

title: Since a $600-a-week benefit lapsed, her savings have been dwindling.
description: Christy Miller says there are three things that shape her identity: making people laugh, making people strong and lifting heavy objects. She cant do any of those right now, and she isnt sure when she will be able to again.

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, were sharing things were eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

title: The TikTok FOMO Is Real
description: As a teen, TikTok creates stress in my life. When I hang out with friends, they often ask if I want to make a TikTok with them. I never suggest it, but it nearly always comes up. I want to be nice and say yes, but then I worry that other friends will see the clip and feel excluded that they werent part of it. At times, TikToks have made me feel separate from my friends, and I dont want to make anyone else feel that. How can I be polite and still respect my friends feelings?

title: A Rising Womens Team Looks Past the Pandemic
description: PARIS  Khadija Shaw sensed opportunity.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in Windsor Terrace, Midtown East and St. George.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Staten Island
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a five-bedroom in Redding, Conn., and a four-bedroom in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Watch live: Fed Chair Jerome Powell speaks on the central banks policy shift.
Fed Chair Sets Stage for Longer Periods of Lower Rates
description: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, announced a major shift in how the central bank guides the economy, signaling it will make job growth pre-eminent and will not raise interest rates to guard against coming inflation just because the unemployment rate is low.

title: Malis Ousted President Is Released From Detention by Coup Leaders
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Ibrahim Boubacar Keta, Malis ousted president, was released from detention and driven to his home in the West African countrys capital early Thursday, nine days after a military coup brought an end to his seven years in power.

title: I Lost Everyone: Floods Bruise a War-Weary Afghanistan
description: CHARIKAR, Afghanistan  Hamid Aghas family was sleeping outside when the rain began. He had witnessed torrential rain before during his two years living in Charikar, a city carved along the foothills of the Hindu Kush in northern Afghanistan, and thought little of it. Yet when the family of 13 awoke on Wednesday, having moved inside their oppressively hot three-room home during the night, it was to the sound of floodwater.

title: Nice White Parents Discussion Guide
description: The podcast Nice White Parents largely focuses on the story of one Brooklyn middle school that opened in 1968  and how white parents have influenced the trajectory of this school over and over, even when their children didnt attend it. But the issues the podcast raises via this one case study make it a meaningful opportunity to explore the complicated realities of race, privilege and power across all American schools.

title: The Dual History of Poisonous Flowers
description: THE FLOWERS POINT straight down, a chandeliers worth, turned ostentatiously away from the sun. They are Brugmansia by genus and angels trumpet in parlance, with elongated buds that open into blaring mouths. In South America, the tree that bears them is called el borrachero, or the drunk-maker, in part because of the blooms dizzying night perfume of fermented lemons, said to induce crazed dreams. And more: Parts of the plant, when crushed, yield scopolamine, a.k.a. burundanga, a.k.a. devils breath  a psychoactive alkaloid deployed by criminals, via a spiked drink or a puff in the face, to disable free will. It is said to transform victims into dutiful servants who revive hours later, bereft of all their belongings and any memory of what theyve done.

title: The Boys Is Back, More Relevant Than Ever
description: Its the penultimate episode of the new season of The Boys, Amazons superhero action series, and its time for a costumed champion named Starlight to give one of those rousing speeches that inspires listeners to ignore insurmountable odds and get motivated for the journey ahead.

title: In His Own Words: Jacob Lawrence at the Met and MoMA
description: Shuttered since March by the coronavirus pandemic, the Museum of Modern Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art are reopening with limited visitorship, various admonitions about masks and social distancing, and several new exhibitions, among them Jacob Lawrence: The American Struggle. That show, at the Met, reunites the panels of a lesser-known series that the storied modernist painted during the mid-1950s, exploring themes from the American Revolution to the Westward expansion.

title: Republicans have intensified their unrest-focused message, with Kenosha as a backdrop.
description: Republicans used the third night of their convention on Wednesday to amplify warnings of violence and lawlessness under Democratic leadership, trying to capitalize on the worsening unrest in Wisconsin to reclaim moderate voters who might be reluctant to hand President Trump a second term.

title: As young Black athletes call for a racial awakening, some N.F.L. retirees declare fealty to Trump.
description: On one of the most consequential nights in recent sports history  when a player-led boycott forced the N.B.A. to postpone playoff games  the Republican National Convention offered pro-Trump testimonials from a retired Notre Dame coach and a former N.F.L. player facing insider-trading charges.

title: How Trumps convention has become a crucial play for the suburbs.
description: It is President Trumps clearest path to re-election: winning back the suburbs in a handful of swing states that drifted from the Republican Party in the 2018 midterms. And that imperative has been vividly apparent each night of the partys national convention, with speakers and videos trying to recast Mr. Trumps divisive record, which hurt Republicans two years ago.

title: The G.O.P. argues that only Trump can stop the chaos. But hes already in charge.
description: The America that many speakers described on Wednesday at the Republican National Convention did not sound like a desirable place: fractious, violent, functionally lawless in some pockets.

title: At no time before have voters faced a clearer choice, Trump will say in his convention address.
description: Amid an untamed pandemic that has cost more than 180,000 American lives and millions of jobs, a hurricane battering the Gulf Coast and unrest gripping another city after another police shooting of a Black man, President Trump plans to make his most direct case for re-election yet on Thursday night when he addresses the Republican National Convention.

title: Some of the immigrants Trump naturalized on Tuesday didnt know they were being broadcast.
description: In one of the most striking moments of the second night of the Republican convention on Tuesday  both for its content and for its blatant disregard for the traditional separation between governing and politicking  President Trump held a naturalization ceremony for five immigrants.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, we offer hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read the latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

title: Hurricane Laura in Pictures
description: Hurricane Laura made landfall near Cameron, La., early Thursday as a Category 4 hurricane, delivering a barrage of 150-mile-per-hour winds and a surge of water. The storm weakened as it moved inland but remained destructive with strong winds and heavy rain.

title: The Billionaire Behind Hudson Yards Thinks New York Is Too Expensive
description: Stephen Ross  the billionaire real estate developer who founded Related Companies, owns the Miami Dolphins and has an interest in brands including SoulCycle and Equinox  is a man of contradictions.

title: Ted Cruz didnt get a convention invite, but he still has plenty to say.
description: Four years ago, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas delivered the most stunning speech of the Republican National Convention, conspicuously declining to endorse Donald J. Trump, his former presidential primary rival, and urging viewers instead to vote your conscience.

title: Dozens of former McCain and Romney staff members back Biden.
description: In contrast to the Democratic convention, where three former presidents and the partys 2016 nominee Hillary Clinton, made the case for Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Republican convention has been devoid of such standard bearers this week for President Trump.

title: Rising Tensions Between Turkey and Greece Divide E.U. Leaders
description: BRUSSELS  An escalating dispute between Greece and Turkey over energy resources in the eastern Mediterranean is fast becoming militarized, raising the risks of a clash among NATO allies.

title: 250 Million Years Ago, They Hibernated at the Bottom of the World
description: How to tell if something that died 250 million years ago hibernated when it was alive?

title: The Personal History of David Copperfield Review: A Boys Story
description: The Personal History of David Copperfield  the umpteenth stab at visualizing Charles Dickenss favorite novel  is so sincere in its telling and so innocently buoyant in its presentation that I had to do a double-take on the writing and directing credits. Armando Iannucci? The Scottish satirist and king of the blisteringly profane diatribe? Surely not.

title: Voluminous Fashions for Dreamy Fall Nights
Fossil Reveals One of the Cutest Dinosaurs Ever Found
description: Some 20 years ago, someone smuggled dinosaur eggs from Argentina to the United States illegally. The smuggler probably had little clue that inside one of the eggs was one of the best-preserved skulls of a dinosaur embryo ever found, which is now giving us new insights into the facial appearance of one line of our planets erstwhile rulers.

title: How to Rein In a Messy Bathroom
description: If every item has a home, youll know where to find it and where to put it when youre done.

title: In Michigans Upper Peninsula, cracks emerge in a pro-Trump wall.
description: ST. IGNACE, Mich.  Michigans Upper Peninsula is known for many things: its enviable location, nestled among three of the five Great Lakes  Huron, Superior and Michigan; hundreds of waterfalls and vast expanses of lush forests; and the pasty, a dough pocket filled with meat, potatoes and vegetables that served as a portable meal for copper and iron miners.

title: Heres how to watch as the convention wraps up.
description: After eight intense nights of programming, the 2020 conventions will come to an end on Thursday: President Trump will formally accept the Republican nomination, and the general election season will officially begin.

title: Putin Warns Belarus Protesters: Dont Push Too Hard
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia gave an ominous warning on Thursday to protesters in Belarus not to push too hard to topple their countrys embattled president, saying that Russia had formed a special reserve force of security officers to restore order in the event of chaos in its western neighbor.

title: Heres What Americas Covid-Era Classrooms Look Like
description: This will be a school year unlike any other, that much is clear. Educators, parents and students across the country are returning to in-person and virtual classrooms shaped by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Watch Report: The Inner Workings
Pelosi says Biden should not debate Trump. Biden disagrees.
description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi, the nations top elected Democrat, said on Thursday that former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. should not debate President Trump, telling reporters that she believed her partys nominee should not dignify that conversation with Donald Trump.

title: TikTok Is Said to Wrestle With Two Competing Offers
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The race to buy TikToks U.S. operations has entered its final stages, with two groups submitting bids for the video app, said three people involved in the deal talks. One of the bids was from Microsoft and Walmart, which have teamed up, and the other was from Oracle and could include a coalition of investors, they said.

title: Trump Barely Mentions Kenosha in Speech, and Only Refers to Violence
description: President Trump made only a glancing reference to Kenosha, Wis., in his speech on Thursday accepting the Republican nomination for a second term, linking it to other American cities where protests against systemic racism and police brutality have sometimes turned violent.

title: Citing Kenosha, a Wisconsin college cancels plans for Pence to deliver its commencement address.
description: The day after Vice President Mike Pence was the headline speaker at the Republican National Convention, a Wisconsin college announced on Thursday that it had decided not to have him deliver its commencement address this weekend.

title: Dennis Williams, Former U.A.W. Leader, Is Accused of Conspiracy
description: Federal prosecutors on Thursday charged a former president of the United Auto Workers union, Dennis Williams, with conspiring to embezzle union funds for personal expenses and luxury travel. He is the 15th person accused in a broad investigation into corruption at the union.

title: One N.B.A. Team Walked Out. A Generation of Athletes Followed.
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.  George Hill is hardly the biggest star in professional basketball. But he was the one who took the lead when a handful of players on the Milwaukee Bucks began talking about the police shooting of Jacob Blake a few days earlier in Wisconsin.

title: Bon Apptits Next Editor in Chief Is a Book-World Star
description: Bon Apptit, the multimedia food-journalism outlet that has experienced a summer of racial strife in the workplace, has a new editor in chief: Dawn Davis, a prominent editor and executive who has been one of the few Black power players in the book world.

title: Trump will appear at a live town hall with undecided voters on ABC next month.
description: President Trump is set to appear at a live town hall with the ABC News anchor George Stephanopoulos on Sept. 15, where he will field questions from undecided voters, the network said Thursday.

title: Reopened Schools Find Health Risks in Water After Covid-19 Lockdowns
description: The new coronavirus is not the only illness that teachers, students, parents and staff will have to worry about as some schools attempt to reopen this fall. Legionella could lurk in the water supplies of school buildings, and some measures to keep people in schools safe from coronavirus may even increase risks from deadly illnesses caused by the bacteria.

title: Bill Arnett, Collector and Promoter of Little-Known Black Art, Dies at 81
description: Bill Arnett had spent two decades collecting and dealing antiquities from around the world  African art was his passion  when, in 1986, he had an epiphany in Birmingham, Ala.

title: Unemployment Claims Are Stubbornly High as Layoffs Persist
description: Just over one million Americans filed new claims for state jobless benefits last week, the latest sign that the economy is losing momentum just as federal aid to the unemployed has been pulled away.

title: Deceptive robocalls try to frighten Detroit residents about voting by mail.
description: The authorities in Michigan said on Thursday they were investigating deceptive robocalls targeting Detroit residents in what appeared to be an effort to deter them from voting by mail.

title: Printer Jam: Serious Supply Issues Disrupt the Book Industrys Fall Season
description: This spring, when the pandemic forced bookstores across the country to close and authors to cancel their tours, many editors and publishers made a gamble. They postponed the publication of dozens of titles, betting that things would be back to normal by the fall.

title: 7 Activities to Build Community and Positive Classroom Culture During Online Learning
description: When schools transitioned to remote learning in the spring, teachers worked quickly to adapt lesson plans and curriculums for virtual classes, while also trying to maintain community and connection. This fall, not only will many educators continue that same work, but they will have the added challenge of building community with students theyve never met.

title: Conway says the more violence erupts, the better it is for Trumps re-election prospects.
description: Kellyanne Conway, President Trumps departing counselor, said on Thursday that Mr. Trump stood to benefit politically from the kind of unrest that erupted this week in Kenosha, Wis., after the police shooting of an unarmed Black man, Jacob Blake.

title: On Smile, Katy Perry Finds Purpose (and Pitfalls) in the Past
description: It is either auspicious, or unfortunate, that Katy Perry is releasing her sixth album, Smile, the same week that her titanically successful 2010 record Teenage Dream is celebrating its 10th birthday.

title: How to Respond to Police Shootings and Mayhem
description: To the Editor:

title: Was the C.D.C. Injected With Politics?
In Trumps Gilded Beltway, Rudy Giuliani Finds a Potent Reward: Relevance
description: WASHINGTON  No one ever asks What happened to Rudy Giuliani? as he hobnobs his way through the lobby of the Trump International Hotel, a few blocks from the White House.

title: 17th-Century Dutch Painting Is Stolen. Again.
description: AMSTERDAM  A 17th-century painting by the Golden Age master Frans Hals was stolen from the wall of a museum in the Netherlands early Wednesday morning.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Officials reported 441 new cases on Thursday, the countrys highest daily total since early March. The government said it was facing two great obstacles in fighting the coronavirus: doctors on strike and churches obstructing epidemiological efforts.

title: Bushs ethics lawyer calls for an investigation of Pompeos R.N.C. speech.
description: Two law professors, including one who served as President George W. Bushs ethics adviser, have filed a complaint to the U.S. Office of Special Counsel accusing Secretary of State Mike Pompeo of violating federal laws by addressing the Republican National Convention while on a diplomatic trip overseas.

title: Plans Are Dumb: The Republican Platform for 2020
description: A (faux) campaign ad for the G.O.P.

title: Walter Lure, Guitarist for a Mythical Punk Band, Dies at 71
description: Walter Lure, who played rhythm guitar for the Heartbreakers, a pioneering band of the 1970s New York punk scene, and who had a most unpunk second career on Wall Street, died on Aug. 21 at in Queens. He was 71.

title: Theater Operator Sues Insurers That Denied It Coronavirus Payments
description: Jujamcyn Theaters, the operator of five Broadway houses, has sued its insurers for denying it millions of dollars that the theater company says it deserves as payment for the losses suffered during the monthslong coronavirus pandemic shutdown.

title: The R.N.C.s TV ratings declined on the third night, lagging the D.N.C.
description: Television ratings declined for Wednesdays installment of the Republican National Convention, which was seen by roughly 25 percent fewer live viewers than the third night of the Democratic convention last week.

title: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Plenty of evidence this week that were living in a boom time for thoughtful, powerful nature writing. Vesper Flights collects essays by Helen Macdonald, whom you likely know from her internationally best-selling memoir, H Is for Hawk. In The Bird Way, Jennifer Ackerman takes a detailed look at the lives of birds  including their parenting strategies  like the bowerbird, the cuckoo and the kea. From the sky to the sea, with another international best seller: Patrik Svenssons The Book of Eels, which combines elements of memoir with an examination of the slithery creatures.

title: G.O.P. Convention Skims Over Trumps Unfinished Business in Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON  The Republican National Convention this week has portrayed President Trump as a strong commander in chief facing down enemies and demanding more of allies, but the boastful language has glossed over the grand ambitions of his foreign policy that he has been unable to fulfill.

title: The Day They Didnt Play
description: It started with empty chairs.

title: How the Met Was Made
description: Talk about a spoiled birthday. For years leading up to its 150th anniversary the Metropolitan Museum of Art had been planning a swell of celebratory programming: an overhaul of its British Galleries, debuts of major gifts of photography and drawing, new cross-cultural displays, an international symposium on collecting, a Great Hall photo op with the mayor and a big cake.

title: Jared Kushner, a real estate scion, says boycotting N.B.A. players have the luxury to take a night off from work.
description: A boycott by N.B.A. players over the shooting of Jacob Blake by police in Kenosha, Wis., elicited a dismissive response from members of the Trump administration on Thursday  one that dramatically diverged from the expressions of solidarity from top Democrats.

title: Israeli Officer Need Not Have Shot Autistic Palestinian, Commander Says
description: JERUSALEM  An Israeli police officer who gunned down a Palestinian man who had autism in the Old City of Jerusalem in May defied an order to hold his fire even though the man posed no danger to anyone, his commander has told investigators, according to people briefed on the case.

title: Douglas A.J. Latchford, Khmer Antiquities Expert, Dies at 88
description: Douglas A.J. Latchford, a pre-eminent collector of Cambodian antiquities who earned praise for his scholarly works on Khmer Empire art, only to be indicted last year by American prosecutors for illicitly trafficking in the selfsame objects, died on Aug. 2 at his home in Bangkok. He was 88.

title: Biden Says Trump Is Rooting for More Violence Amid Kenosha Unrest
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Thursday accused President Trump of rooting for more violence at a moment of national unrest over racism and police brutality, offering one of his most extensive responses yet to the Republican argument that he would be a weak leader on law enforcement and criminal justice.

title: The Elite Needs to Give Up Its G.D.P. Fetish
description: For Americans living through the recent months of crisis, some of the latest economic data may come as a surprise. Gross Domestic Product (G.D.P.) over the past six months remained far above what we could have achieved even a decade ago. Investors have driven key stock indexes back above their February peaks. But rarely have such economic indicators been so entirely beside the point. Seriously: Who cares?

title: Charles Cook, Ground Zero Volunteer for Months, Dies at 79
description: When the planes crashed into the World Trade Center towers on Sept. 11, 2001, most people streamed uptown.

title: The pandemic has curbed new voter registrations, but a study suggests a reason for hope.
description: Despite immense interest in Novembers elections, new-voter registrations have plummeted this year, thanks to a pandemic that has shut down motor-vehicle licensing offices and get-out-the-vote drives by advocacy groups at places like malls and street festivals.

title: The British Museum Reopens to a World That Has Changed
description: LONDON  After being closed for 163 days by the coronavirus pandemic, the British Museum on Thursday became the last of Europes major museums to welcome back visitors.

title: White House Wants Companies to Foot Payroll Tax Bill for Workers
description: WASHINGTON  A debate between the White House and the Treasury Department over President Trumps payroll tax suspension has delayed crucial information about how the executive order will be carried out, according to people familiar with the matter, leaving businesses across the country uncertain about how to proceed.

title: How Much Can 1968 Tell Us About 2020?
description: I was awakened, early on May 29, by a reporter asking what I thought about the presidents latest tweet; that was how I first learned the most powerful man in the world had just said of the nationwide disturbances breaking out over the police murder of George Floyd, When the looting starts, the shooting starts. It portended a busy week.

title: When Hurricanes Lead to Industrial Fires, Minority Neighborhoods Can Take a Hit
description: A fire blazed, and acrid smoke poured from a Louisiana chemical factory, confirming fears that Hurricane Lauras ravaging winds and water would release toxic pollution in a region central to the petrochemical industry that is increasingly exposed to major storms.

title: Rudy Giuliani, who went from Americas mayor to the presidents personal lawyer, will speak Thursday night.
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani  a kind of at-large fixer and henchman for President Trump, first under the guise of informal security consultant and then as his personal lawyer  will speak Thursday night, Mark Leibovich writes in a memo on the Republican Convention. Mr. Leibovich explored the moment, and the arc of Mr. Giulianis long career:

title: Officer Implicated in Kenosha Shooting Is on the Departments Bike Squad
description: Rusten Sheskey, the police officer who authorities say shot Jacob Blake in the back on Sunday, is a seven-year veteran of the Kenosha Police Department who long aspired to a law enforcement career and once described police work as a customer service job, and the public is our customer.

title: This Confederate Monument Survived Protests, but Not the Hurricane
description: As protests against police violence and white supremacy swept away dozens of longstanding memorials to the Confederacy this summer, a 105-year-old monument on the courthouse lawn in Lake Charles, La., remained standing.

title: Hurricane Laura, President Trump, Baby Dinosaurs: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Do Not Vote for My Dad: When Families Disagree on Politics
description: Chris Ojeda, assistant professor of political science at the University of Tennessee, who studies childrens political beliefs.

title: No Bushes, Reagans, Cheneys or McCains: Who Is Missing at Trumps R.N.C.
description: The Republican National Convention has been a four-day procession of police officers, soldiers, religious leaders, mothers, White House aides, Trump family members and up-and-coming party stars, all singing the praises of President Trump. But one group seems to have been left out of the show: the once-dominant Republican establishment that ruled before Mr. Trump.

title: What if Facebook Is the Real Silent Majority?
description: Listen, liberals. If you dont think Donald Trump can get re-elected in November, you need to spend more time on Facebook.

title: What to Watch For: The Night Trump Has Been Waiting For
description: [Watch the convention live with real-time analysis and fact-checking from our reporters.]

title: Is Ivanka Trump Going to Change Anyones Mind?
description: On night four of the Republican National Convention, viewers knew her as The Honorable Ivanka Trump.

title: U.S. Open Draw Lacks Some Stars, but Not Story Lines
description: After months of hesitation and uncertainty in the tennis world, a welcome development arrived on Thursday: the mens and womens singles draws for the United States Open.

title: Coronavirus Winter Is Coming
description: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Hurricane Laura slammed into the Louisiana and Texas coasts overnight, sending residents in areas hit hard by the coronavirus pandemic scrambling to find shelter. The hurricane was among the strongest storms ever to hit the U.S., and more than 500,000 residents in its path were urged to leave their homes.

title: With Walkouts, a New High Bar for Protests in Sports Is Set
description: It was the silence that spoke loudest.

title: Gerald D. Hines, Developer and Architects Medici, Is Dead at 95
description: Gerald D. Hines, a soft-spoken engineer who started out as a builder of small, anonymous warehouses in Houston and went on to transform the business of commercial real estate development by hiring blue-chip architects to build commercial skyscrapers around the globe, died on Sunday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 95.

title: Trump and the Politics of Mean World
description: Ive been thinking about the two families weve encountered over the past two weeks. The Biden family is emotionally open, rendered vulnerable by tragedy and driven by a powerful desire to connect. The Trump family is emotionally closed, isolated by enmity and driven by a powerful desire to dominate.

title: April Was Trumps Cruelest Month
description: On Wednesday, Vice President Mike Pence peddled an extraordinary fantasy about Donald Trumps handling of the coronavirus. Pences tale of heroic, decisive leadership was so completely at odds with reality that pretty much the only words he spoke that werent lies were a, and, and the.

title: How to Help Hurricane Laura Victims
description: Hurricane Laura, one of the strongest storms on record to hit the United States, devastated areas of the Louisiana and Texas coasts when it made landfall on Thursday. Many fled their homes to escape the path of the storm, which has killed at least four people and left hundreds of thousands without power.

title: Despite the virus, Trump will speak in front of a large crowd, seated closely together on the South Lawn.
description: President Trump will speak Thursday night in front of a large crowd sitting closely together on the South Lawn of the White House without significant social distancing, according to photos of the event space taken Thursday afternoon.

title: The World Outside
description: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. Im Giovanni Russonello, typically the morning newsletter writer, covering the evening shift during the conventions.

title: Will This Be the Year Arizona Turns Blue?
description: Arizona has long been a testing ground for anti-immigrant laws and talk, but the state has seen a political shift. Analysts suggests that demographic changes, including a growing number of transplants from more liberal states and Latino voters, are responsible for the shift. This is partially true, but the origins of Arizonas evolution into a pivotal battleground state can be attributed to a longer history and a broader cast of characters.

title: N.B.A. Boycott or Strike: Whats the Difference?
description: Athletes across the N.B.A., the W.N.B.A., Major League Baseball and Major League Soccer refused to play games on Wednesday after the police shooting of Jacob Blake in Kenosha, Wis., on Sunday.

title: C.D.C.s Clarification on Coronavirus Testing Offers More Confusion
description: WASHINGTON  The director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, seeking to clarify recommendations on coronavirus testing that incited an uproar, said that testing may be considered for all close contacts of confirmed or probable Covid-19 patients.

title: Bill & Ted Face the Music Review: Be Adequate to Each Other
description: Bill & Ted Face the Music sounds like more of a reckoning than it is. It would be unbearable to think that William Preston and Theodore Logan, the goofballs first incarnated by Alex Winter and Keanu Reeves more than 30 years ago, could be candidates for cancellation. And though they may be longer in the tooth and heavier in the jowl than they used to be  as so many of us are  the dudes retain their essential innocence. They are still friendly avatars of nontoxic masculinity. No serious misdeeds resurface from their various time travels that demand judgment in the harsh light of the present.

title: It Gives Me Chills: An N.B.A. Player Talks Profiling and Protests
description: As John Henson approached the front door of a high-end jewelry store in suburban Milwaukee on Oct. 19, 2015, he noticed a police cruiser across the street. He did not think much of it until he heard the door to the store click  and he realized that someone had triggered the lock.

title: Instead of Evolving as President, Trump Has Bent the Job to His Will
description: WASHINGTON  For a man on the edge of history, President Trump sounded calm and relaxed. If he believes that he is on the verge of losing, he betrayed no sign of it. Instead, he trotted out one of his favorite polls, boasted about his popularity with Republican voters and talked about his conventions television ratings.

title: Trump Heads Into General Election He Casts as a Crusade for Law and Order
description: President Trump accepted the Republican Partys nomination for a second term on Thursday, joining a general-election contest against Joseph R. Biden Jr. that he and his party cast this week as a crusade against left-wing ideology and violent social disorder, fought against the backdrop of a virus that Republicans largely described as a temporary handicap on the economy.

title: Full Analysis: Final Night of the Republican National Convention
description: President Trump headlined the fourth and final night of the Republican convention. Our correspondents followed every revelation and provided live analysis and insights.

title: Suspect in Kenosha Killings Lionized the Police
description: He signed up to be a cadet in a program for teenagers who aspire to be police officers. He filled his Facebook page with support for Blue Lives Matter. He sat upfront at a rally for President Trump in January, and posted images of it on TikTok. And he chose to mark his 16th birthday by raising funds for a support group for the police called Humanizing the Badge.

title: Jackson Heights, Queens: Walk Where the World Finds a Home
description: Stroll through the citys most global neighborhood with the author Suketu Mehta, featuring Diversity Plaza, Roosevelt Avenue and the birth of Scrabble.

title: Mets G.M. Rebukes Commissioner but Apologizes, Citing Misunderstanding
description: The Mets and the Miami Marlins chose not to play on Thursday, joining 12 other Major League Baseball teams in sitting out in response to the police shooting of a Black man in Kenosha, Wis.

title: Hurricane Laura Carves Destructive Path Across Louisiana
description: [Follow our live Hurricane Sally updates and our map tracker.]

title: Dan Scavino Equates His and Countrys Relationship With Trump
description: The presidents social media director spoke about working for Mr. Trump for nearly 30 years, and marveled at his leadership. He saw my potential, even when I couldnt, Mr. Scavino said.

title: Ben Carson Defends Trump on Race
description: The secretary of housing and urban development shared anecdotes of President Trump helping Black Americans before and during his time in office.

title: Italy Foreign Minister Shares Blackface Images of His Summer Tan
description: In one image, he was a new relative in the Huxtable family from The Cosby Show. In another, his face was superimposed on the body of Michael Jordan as he glided to the rim. In another, he was placed in a scene from a classic Italian film in which the actor Tot, wearing blackface, plays an ambassador from a fictional African country.

title: Get on Board
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  It will come as no surprise to anyone that, where there is an explosion of people wanting to solve crossword puzzles, there will be an explosion of people wanting to make crossword puzzles. For some, you can fill in only so many squares before you start to wonder how the cruciverbal sausage is made.

title: Damage From Hurricane Laura Seen From Above
description: Parts of the Louisiana coast were ravaged by Hurricane Laura. This drone footage shows the scale of devastation.

title: Donald Trump Has Changed Washington
description: Ivanka Trump introduced her father at the Republican National Convention, extolling his unconventional methods and ensuring the crowd he would deliver four more years of the same.

title: Donald Trump Accepts Nomination and Attacks Biden
description: Giving a speech in turns self-congratulatory and alarmist, the president said that if given the chance, Joe Biden would be the destroyer of American greatness.

title: Will They See Me as a Son, a Daughter or a Stranger?
description: Unlike my mothers usual emails (with the entire message crammed into the subject line), this one had no text, only an attached photo. I clicked on the file and reeled at the picture of her, emaciated, with a deep gash above her bruised eye.

title: A Doctor Asks: Is Covid Scaring Us Away From Our Humanity?
description: Soren Kierkegaard wrote that Life can only be understood backwards; but it must be lived forwards. I wonder how this time of Covid will appear in retrospect.

title: Belarus, Donald Trump, Hurricane Laura: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Trump Stomps on the Rules, but the Pandemic Isnt as Easily Trampled
description: President Trump made a dramatic entrance from the South Portico to deliver a searing attack on Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his party, seeking to transform the 2020 race from a referendum on his presidency and handling of the coronavirus pandemic into a choice between two starkly different visions of America.

title: Quotation of the Day: Fed Chair Paves Way for a Period of Lower Rates
description: Inflation that is persistently too low can pose serious risks to the economy.

title: Corrections: Aug. 28, 2020
description: An article on Thursday about the impact that the unrest in Wisconsin is having on voter preferences misstated the surname of a waitress at a pizza restaurant in Kenosha, Wis. She is Priscella Gazda, not Gazza.

title: Whats on TV Friday: Following and The Roads Not Taken
description: FOLLOWING (1998) Stream on Criterion Channel and IFC Films Unlimited; rent on Amazon, Google Play, iTunes and YouTube. When hardy audiences trek to theaters to see Christopher Nolans latest mind-bender, Tenet, in theaters next week, they can expect two things: masks in the movie house and puzzles on the screen. For that has been the Nolan way for nearly two decades: In 2001, Nolans Memento offered a series of clever epistemological puzzles, A.O. Scott wrote in his review for The New York Times. Nolans film The Prestige, from 2006, has a satisfyingly puzzlelike structure, Scott wrote in his review. The filmmakers 2010 dream-hopper, Inception? It trades in crafty puzzles, Scott wrote. Interstellar in 2014? Tantalizing puzzles, Manohla Dargis wrote. All echo Following, Nolans 1998 debut feature, which gave a taste of his knack for cinematic discombobulation. Shot on a shoestring  the cost of making Following, reported to be in the low thousands, was surely less than the hair gel budget delegated to the men of Inception  the film plays fast and loose with chronology, telling the story of a young Londoner (Jeremy Theobald), whose hobby of tailing strangers leads him to the citys criminal underbelly. In her review for The Times, Janet Maslin called the movie a black-and-white film noir with a difference, writing that the usual elements of scheming and deception are well represented here, but they are made all the knottier by shifting time frames. And, she noted, the story offers plenty of intriguing puzzle pieces.

But some independent family businesses in the metropolitan area  all deemed essential  not only operated throughout the worst part of the outbreak and are still going strong, but also survived 20th-century crises like the Great Depression and World War II. Here are a few of them.

To be clear, last years Venice Film Festival promised journalists more than just the world premiere of that Todd Phillips supervillain origin story, then only an operatically pitched trailer. There would also be Brad Pitt in the space psychodrama Ad Astra, Noah Baumbachs emotionally charged Marriage Story, and a new film by Hirokazu Kore-eda, the Japanese master who only a year earlier had made the devastating Shoplifters.

(Hello, bipartisan punching bag Mayor Bill de Blasio.) Of course, this is President Trumps party. And if there were any chance you might forget that, his hourlong speech followed by a massive fireworks display  complete with TRUMP 2020 spelled out in fireworks  was there to remind you.

A computational neuroscientist at the University of California, Berkeley, Dr. Gallant worked for years to improve our understanding of how brains encode information  what regions become active, for example, when a person sees a plane or an apple or a dog  and how that activity represents the object being viewed.

He is not dashing between Moscow and Milan, London and Sydney, readjusting to time zones, settling into rented apartments, reconnecting with favorite partners and old friends. Mr. Hallberg, 38, who made ballet history in 2011 by becoming the first American to join the Bolshoi Ballet as a principal, is not rehearsing and performing in Eugene Onegin, Giselle, The Winters Tale or Nureyev some of the ballets he was supposed to dance this year, with the Bolshoi Ballet, American Ballet Theater, the Royal Ballet and La Scala Ballet.

Since Covid-19 hit, Ms. Dela Cruzs mother has been living with the family as well, meaning that Ms. Dela Cruz and her husband share one bedroom with their children while her mother is in the other.

title: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love The Sting
description: Frankly, I didnt understand The Sting when it opened in 1973 and I was 10. What with the movies manifold tricks and streetwise double-crossings, I grasped only the basics. In 1930s gangland Chicago, two handsome, sneaky crooks (Paul Newman and Robert Redford) were swindling another handsome, far more sinister crook (Robert Shaw). This they do by trying to fleece him of half a million dollars in a bogus betting parlor, populated by a mob of their associates. What I liked most were the mustaches.

title: A Sculptural Sofa, Rereleased for the First Time
description: Several of the museum shows that set the cultural course of the late 20th century took place in a single year: 1972. In addition to the Documenta 5 exhibition in Kassel, Germany, a wide-ranging spectacle that signaled the rise of mass media, and the British Museums Treasures of Tutankhamun, which opened not only the Egyptian pharaohs tomb but the floodgate for traveling blockbusters, there was the Museum of Modern Arts Italy: The New Domestic Landscape. Twelve legendary Italian designers and design groups were invited to create environments in the museums galleries, while dozens more presented their works in the sculpture garden, among them Achille and Pier Giacomo Castiglionis Arco arching lamp and the Olivetti Valentine typewriter by Ettore Sottsass, who would later lead the colorful Memphis collective.

title: The Psychiatrist Will See You Online Now
description: For about two years, Michael Raymos made the drive from Modesto, Calif., to Sacramento and back for therapy, and for the therapist, who could listen to stories of childhood abuse and gently unwind their hold on the present. Those regular office sessions, at a clinic at the University of California, Davis, created a strong bond, and Mr. Raymos came to rely on them to manage symptoms of post-traumatic stress and the emotional weight of a neurodegenerative disorder that struck him in 2012, in the prime of adulthood.

title: When Retirement Comes Too Early
description: Joey Himelfarb estimates that in his 25 years in sales, hawking everything from Hewlett-Packard computers to cars and swimming pools, he has been laid off or downsized at least a half-dozen times.

description: NADOR, Morocco  For months, Boubacar Wann Diallo could not sleep at night without leaving a light on.

title: Fabrics With Powerful Stories to Tell
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Tucked away on a bottom shelf in Sonia Gomess studio here is a small cardboard box. Inside, two scarves  one woven in mustard-colored cashmere and the other in a printed silk  are carefully folded. A handwritten letter sits on top.

Biden Jr. that he and his party cast this week as a crusade against left-wing ideology and violent social disorder, fought against the backdrop of a virus that Republicans largely described as a temporary handicap on the economy.

title: A Visitors Guide to MoMA and the Met
description: Before you head back to the Museum of Modern Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, there are some things you need to know: capacity will be limited to 25 percent, temperature checks and face masks will be mandatory, and the advance purchase of tickets is required. Each museum has specific guidelines, so youll want to visit their websites: moma.org and metmuseum.org. Our critics have reviewed some of the new shows  Flix Fnon at MoMA, and Making the Met, Jacob Lawrence and Hctor Zamoras rooftop sculpture at the Met  but they also weighed in previously about several exhibitions that are still on view. Below, youll find an overview of those shows, as well as a partial listing of some of the museums opening in the coming days. NICOLE HERRINGTON

title: He Did What?: On Trump, Merkels Face Does the Talking
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany refuses as a rule to comment on the internal affairs of other countries or pass judgment on their leaders. The president of the United States is no exception.

title: Children in a World Gone Mad: 5 Kids Books Set During World War II

title: Jackie O.s Bag of Choice, Rebranded in Her Name
description: ITS A FAMILIAR picture: a post-Camelot Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, with her windswept coif, giant tortoiseshell glasses and that classic saddlebag perpetually swung over one arm. The story goes that the former first lady used Guccis slouchy leather tote, originally named the G1244, to shield herself from the paparazzi. In the 70s and 80s, she was photographed carrying the bag so often  arriving at her Manhattan apartment, whizzing through Heathrow Airport  that the Italian fashion house at some point began internally referring to it as the Jackie.

title: France Prohibits a Bird Hunting Technique, 41 Years After an E.U. Ban
description: PARIS  The hunting technique involves coating branches with glue to trap songbirds, which are caged to attract additional birds that can then be killed.

When the progressive economist and I arranged to meet last December in a Midtown Manhattan coffee shop, I was expecting someone buttoned up, and I couldnt find her in the room. Then she texted and waved from just a few feet away. She was wearing a Stephen Malkmus and the Jicks T-shirt  a niche band featuring the lead singer of the beloved 1990s indie group Pavement.

description: Shes called Hollywood for a reason. No one shines brighter than Atlanta Dream guard Chennedy Carter when the lights are on.

title: Investing in Social Good Is Finally Becoming Profitable
description: Impact investments, which aim to promote a social good or prevent a social ill, have significantly outperformed traditional bets during the coronavirus pandemic. And their returns are enticing hesitant investors to rework their portfolios.

title: Spotting $62 Million in Alleged P.P.P. Fraud Was the Easy Part
description: The criminal complaints read like catalogs of luxury bling: a diamond-laden $52,000 Rolex, a gambling spree at the Bellagio, two Lamborghinis, a pair of Cadillac Escalades, a Rolls-Royce. All that and more, law enforcement officials said, was financed through schemes to defraud the federal governments signature coronavirus relief program for small businesses.

title: Blackpink and Selena Gomezs Summery Treat, and 11 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

title: Athletes Are Finished Playing Americas Rigged Game
description: In June, as the National Basketball Association prepared to restart its season amid the twin crises of the pandemic and the nationwide protests against racial injustice, the general manager of one team told the sportswriter Sam Amick, You know and I know why we are playing  for the money.

title: Japans Prime Minister Resigns Due to Illness
description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan announced on Friday that he would resign because of health concerns, and apologized for stepping down during the pandemic.

A Lighter, Brighter Meatball

title: Director of a Storied Paris Theater Is Fired
description: LONDON  Ruth Mackenzie broke boundaries as the artistic director of the Thtre du Chtelet, one of Paris most famous stages.

title: Todays Chefs Are Honoring a Vital Tradition: Feeding the Revolution
description: THE KITCHEN IS an arsenal. Bring out the pots and pans and bang them like drums, clash lids, whack spoons. That the weapons are so humble is the point: everyday essentials, available to all. Orchestras equipped like this once paraded through medieval Europe, in the traditions of the French charivari and its English equivalent, rough music, descending on the homes of those believed to have betrayed social mores  what the English folk historian Violet Alford called the beginning of popular justice. This took on a more political tone in the mid-19th century, with housewives in Paris bashing pans outside their landlords windows, demanding relief from rent. Today, such disruptive noisemaking has been borrowed as a form of collective action around the world, often under the name cacerolazo (from the Spanish for casserole), popularized by a 1971 demonstration against food shortages in Chile in which more than 5,000 women took to the streets rattling pots, the emptiness of which gave testament to their cause.

title: New York Gyms Are Reopening. Will Group Fitness Still Thrive Outside?
description: Party in the park.

title: Two P.R. Experts at F.D.A. Have Been Ousted After Blood Plasma Fiasco
description: The head of the Food and Drug Administration ousted its top spokeswoman from her position on Friday in an urgent bid to restore the tarnished credibility of the agency after he made erroneous claims that overstated the benefits of plasma treatments for Covid-19 at a news conference with President Trump.

title: Does My Kid Have a Cold or Is It Covid-19?
description: Its inevitable. In the fall and winter your child is likely to develop a fever, runny nose or cough. Maybe even all three.

title: The 2020 Party Conventions Gave New Meaning to Political Theater
description: The largely virtual format of the Republican and Democratic national conventions meant that even more than usual, the messages were embedded within the visual presentation. Here Vanessa Friedman, the chief fashion critic for The New York Times, and James Poniewozik, the chief television critic, discuss what they saw and what it all meant.

title: Slow Cooker Central
description: Hello, and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. Its no secret to anyone who knows me that I love my slow cooker. (Ive used it so much that the temperature markings have worn off, and Ive had to write over them with a Sharpie.) Slow cookers get a bad rap for many reasons, but, for a lot of busy home cooks, they are a lifesaver. The key is choosing your recipes wisely.

title: Here are 3 key moments from the final night of the Republican convention.
description: In addition to President Trumps lengthy speech from the South Lawn of the White House, the last night of the Republican National Convention featured relentless attacks on Joseph R. Biden Jr. and an appearance from a prominent member of the Republican establishment: Senator Mitch McConnell, the House majority leader. New York Times reporters Jennifer Medina and Sydney Ember discussed their big takeaways from the final night. Here are excerpts from their conversation:

title: Schools Briefing: The Rise of Off-Off-Off-Campus Housing
description: Some college students will spend this semester in their childhood bedrooms. Others are taking their chances on campuses.

title: Clouds of Smoke are Blowing Misery Across the West
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif.  Another morning without a sunrise. As forests burned in the distance, the leaden sky smelled like a campfire. Air-quality sensors glowed red. And once again, Dave Begley, a lumberjack who has been sleeping in his truck here since fleeing Californias wildfires, woke up straining to breathe.

title: Trump made false and misleading claims about the coronavirus, the economy, himself and his opponent.
description: This figure, which calculates the number of people known to have the coronavirus who ultimately die from the disease, is currently just above 3 percent in the United States, putting it in roughly the top third of countries afflicted by the coronavirus.

title: The Met Operas Newest Star Returns, on the Small Screen

title: A Word Not Uttered by Republican Officials at the Convention: Obamacare
description: In 2012, right in the middle of his convention speech, Mitt Romney declared the repeal of Obamacare a crucial priority. It was part of his five-part plan for a better future.

title: Review: Chloroform, Lies and Racism Fire Up The Jacksonian
description: Fred Weber, a proud son of Mississippi and one very scary bartender, is said to have astoundingly acute peripheral vision. Watching the immensely enjoyable (and equally disturbing) reading of Beth Henleys The Jacksonian, which streamed live on Thursday night as part of the New Group Off Stage series, you dont doubt that Fred  played by a priceless Bill Pullman  can detect whatevers beside him, behind him or above him.

title: Will More Data Make Us Healthier?

title: The True Cost of Lionel Messis Declaration of Independence

Basketball hoops are replaced by full-sized courts. Perfectly manicured gardens roll down the slopes. Blooms of bougainvillea pour over walls. Lionel Messis place is the last one on the left.

title: Linda Manz, Young Star of Days of Heaven, Dies at 58
description: Linda Manz, an artfully sullen actress who won glowing reviews as the narrator and the little sister in Terrence Malicks haunting 1978 film, Days of Heaven, died on Aug. 14. She was 58.

title: The Beer Industry Looks for Ways to Help Black Brewers
description: Garrett Oliver had planned to spend the spring flying to Brazil, Sweden, Japan and three other countries for book promotions and beer events. But the coronavirus shutdown grounded Mr. Oliver, the brewmaster at Brooklyn Brewery, and left him flush with free time.

title: Merkel, charmed by Trump? Germans arent so sure.
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany refuses as a rule to comment on the internal affairs of other countries or pass judgment on their leaders. But that hasnt stopped her from letting her face do the talking, reflecting confusion, befuddlement or exasperation regarding President Trump as the situation required. On Friday, she was at it again.

description: LONDON  A trucking company manager from Northern Ireland pleaded guilty on Friday to the manslaughter of 39 Vietnamese people, including two 15-year-old boys, whose bodies were found last year in a truck trailer in Essex, east of London.

Its one thing to ignore the opposing political opinions of a friend or a co-worker, but when your spouse has drastically different political views  it can put a strain on your relationship. And, with the presidential race in full swing, politically-divided couples find themselves at odds now more than ever.

description: If you were to create a chart showing the hierarchical position of each of President Trumps four adult children, judging from how often he sees, mentions or is photographed with them, you would surely place the golden child of the family, Ivanka Trump, at the very top. Next would come the two sons  Donald Trump Jr. and Eric.

title: End of the Line: School Bus Industry in Crisis Because of the Coronavirus
description: WASHINGTON  When Glenn Every received notice in early March that schools in the Hudson Valley of New York would close because of the coronavirus pandemic, he parked his fleet of 20 school buses thinking they would be running again in a few months.

title: After 7 Years on the Run, a Muslim Brotherhood Leader Is Caught
description: CAIRO  Egypts interior ministry said Friday that a security services raid on a Cairo apartment had captured Mahmoud Ezzat, the acting leader of the outlawed Muslim Brotherhood, who had been on the run for seven years.

description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee announced on Friday that it would move to hold Secretary of State Mike Pompeo in contempt of Congress for defying its subpoenas related to the State Departments participation in Senate Republicans investigation targeting the Bidens.

title: Heres What You Need to Know About Donald G. McNeil Jr.
description: Since February, Donald G. McNeil Jr. has been our go-to guide for understanding the coronavirus. He warned us in February, before the outbreak was classified as a pandemic, that it may soon become a global health crisis, and in March, when everything still felt new and uncertain, he offered essential advice on how to avoid infection. This week, he joined us again to explain four recent developments on our understanding of the virus.

title: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
description: Welcome to the weekend. Can you believe were already in the last few days of August? Maybe you or your loved ones are gearing up for a return to school. This summers been a tough one, but I hope youve managed to get some moments of rest. Whatever youre doing this weekend, be sure to make time for some great journalism.

title: Alice Koller, Author of the Solitary Life, Dies at 94
description: At 37, Alice Koller was unsettled. She had a Ph.D. in philosophy from Harvard, a rsum of small-bore jobs in and out of academia and no fixed address. She was bright and educated, yet she had floundered.

title: Nxivm Sex Cult Leader Should Get Life in Prison, Prosecutors Say
description: The self-help group Nxivm gained notoriety as a sex cult last year when its leader, Keith Raniere, was convicted of sex trafficking, racketeering and conspiracy after testimony that he had created a harem of sexual slaves, branded with his initials and kept in line with blackmail.

title: Larry Pardey, Mariner Who Sailed the World Engineless, Dies at 80
description: On a perilous westerly course bound for Cape Horn near the southern tip of South America in 2002, Larry and Lin Pardey made their approach into the hazardous currents of the Strait of Le Maire aboard Taleisin, their 29-foot, engineless wooden yacht.

title: The People Youd Pay Admission to Know
description: Welcome. I recently received a message on social media from a long-lost friend. Wed been inseparable in college, co-conspirators, ecstatic with newfound freedom that manifested in what, decades on, I see in a montage from a film that could be described as a heartwarming coming-of-age caper: Gossipy late-night dorm-room study sessions. Swapping clothes. Dancing deliriously at an on-campus concert of the Village People. A spring break trip to New York where we bought matching wool berets and wore them to what to us was the citys coolest nightclub, the Limelight.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Vacations have become a serious point of contention among families, friends and strangers on social media, who say travelers may be unnecessarily putting their health in jeopardy, or unknowingly spreading the virus to others.

title: Movies Are Returning to Theaters. Will Audiences Follow?
description: HENDERSON, Nev.  The Regal Sunset Station multiplex in suburban Las Vegas reopened on Thursday night after sitting empty for five months in eerie pandemic-forced exile. One of the first people to take a center seat, popcorn and orange soda in hand, was Brian Truitt, who bought tickets to The New Mutants, a Marvel superhero movie, a week in advance.

title: Trump Says Crime Is Rampant in N.Y.C. Here Are the Facts.
description: When President Trump sought to paint an apocalyptic portrait of big-city crime as out of control at the Republican National Convention Thursday night, he turned to two fellow New Yorkers to help him make the case.

title: Conventions Can Boost the Incumbent. Did It Work This Time?
description: The last two presidential re-election campaigns followed a similar playbook: define the opposition early on the most important issue, emphasize a few cultural wedge issues to rally the base while appealing to a few swing voters, and reinvigorate supporters at the convention. It was enough for George W. Bush in 2004 and Barack Obama in 2012 to flip their approval ratings from negative to positive, and to win re-election.

title: Jacob Blake, Plasma, September Books: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: With a New Leader, Conservatives Look to Unseat Justin Trudeau
description: In keeping with the general upheaval that has marked this year, the Conservative Party of Canada announced its new leader at an unusual time: in the middle of the United States presidential nominating conventions.

title: The New Mutants Review: Maybe All the Cool Super Powers Were Taken
description: How does one disavow an unruly mutant? Lock it up, says the Essex Corporation, the villain of The New Mutants, an X-Men-adjacent thriller about a detention hall for ultra-destructive kids  and 20th Century Studios, the manufacturer of this ramshackle flick, agrees. Directed in 2017 by Josh Boone (The Fault in Our Stars), The New Mutants spent three years on ice before being allowed to escape into the slowest summer season in a century. Thats fitting for a film thats all buildup and no bang.

title: 2 TikTok Stars Who Threw Big Parties Face Charges, Prosecutors Say
description: The TikTok stars Bryce Hall and Blake Gray are facing criminal charges for throwing mega-parties at their Hollywood Hills mansion in defiance of a ban against large gatherings in Los Angeles, prosecutors announced on Friday.

title: We Need to Adapt: California Unveils New Virus Reopening Plan
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom said Californias plan to reopen businesses would be based on a system of tiers, tied to positive tests and new cases of the coronavirus.

title: N.Y.C. Tenants Say They Were Tricked Into Appearing in R.N.C. Video
description: It started with an unexpected call last week from Lynne Patton, a longtime Trump associate who oversees federal housing programs in New York.

title: After a Long Lull, Protesting Is Taking Hold Across Baseball
description: Carlos Delgado, the former Toronto Blue Jays and Mets slugger, was playing basketball with his 13-year-old son at their home in Puerto Rico on Wednesday evening when he noticed a news alert on his phone: The Milwaukee Bucks players were sitting out of their N.B.A. playoff game to protest systemic racism and police brutality following the shooting of Jacob Blake, a Black man, by police in Kenosha, Wis.

title: An American Disaster Foretold
description: PARIS  Henry Kissinger this month called Franois Delattre, the former French ambassador to the United States who is now the secretary general of the Foreign Ministry. Kissinger was concerned about the deteriorating state of U.S.-Chinese relations and the risk that the situation could slip out of control.

title: The Massacre That Emboldened White Supremacists
description: An hour after sunset on Easter Sunday in 1873, a stern-wheel riverboat put ashore at Colfax, La., a ramshackle settlement surrounded by cotton plantations on the east bank of the Red River. Rain was falling. As passengers disembarked, they found themselves stumbling in the dark over what turned out to be the lifeless bodies of African-Americans who had been freed from slavery eight years earlier at the conclusion of the Civil War.

title: The Conventions Hit Closer to Home This Year
description: The faces flicker across our screens, making a pitch in speech and song to voters who may or may not be listening. To document the national political conventions in this pandemic year, Damon Winter went into ordinary peoples homes in upstate New York and projected images from the live broadcasts across bedrooms, living rooms, kitchens, basements  wherever the residents typically watch or listen to the news. The photographs he took of these projections capture the strangeness of this years conventions, and how dramatically they differed from the events in a typical year.

title: TV Ratings for Biden and Trump Signal an Increasingly Polarized Nation
description: Americans who watched the political conventions on television opted for news networks with partisan fan bases to a degree unseen in recent years, another sign of an increasingly divided electorate as the nation hurtles toward the November election.

title: Bill for Trumps Tax Holiday Will Be Due Next Year, Treasury Dept. Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Treasury Department released guidance on Friday evening instructing companies that they can stop withholding payroll taxes paid by employees beginning on Sept. 1 but that workers will have to pay the taxes by the end of April.

title: Lute Olson, Who Put Arizona on College Basketball Map, Dies at 85
description: Lute Olson, a Basketball Hall of Fame coach who took the University of Arizona to the 1997 N.C.A.A. championship and 23 consecutive appearances in the postseason tournament, died on Thursday in Tucson, Ariz. He was 85.

title: Dead Dolphins Wash Ashore After Oil Spill Off Mauritius
description: Environmentalists are expressing alarm over an increasing number of dead dolphins that have washed ashore on Mauritius after a Japanese ship ran aground last month, spilling oil into the famed blue lagoons off the Indian Ocean island.

title: Rival Themes Emerge as Race Enters Final Weeks: Covid vs. Law and Order
description: As a weeklong Republican offensive against Joseph R. Biden Jr. ends, the Democratic nominee plans to resume campaigning in swing states and has released a multimillion dollar barrage of ads attacking President Trumps handling of the coronavirus.

title: Quotation of the Day: Panting for Air Under Smoky Western Skies
description: It was one patient after another, every 15 minutes, wheezing, unable to sleep. Its terrible.

title: Corrections: Aug. 29, 2020
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption with an article on Page 4 about the golden age of televised theater misidentifies the production company for Twelve Angry Men. It was Studio One, not Playhouse 90.

description: Over the past week, the Republican National Convention sought to conjure a radical left hellscape.

title: Sarah Palins Suit Against New York Times Will Go to Trial, Judge Rules
